author: {'steamid': '76561198068534122', 'num_games_owned': 317, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 8717, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5035, 'last_played': 1682950683}
review:
So I've got about 100 legitimate hours of playing this game. That's split between playing the singleplayer, building ships for tournaments, watching my ships compete in tournaments, and sharing and battling ships with friends.

This is, in all honesty, one of the best space-ship games I've ever played. The game itself is built on very simple components: simple physics, simple graphics, and simple 2-D exploration. However, it is the way these parts fit together under the fantastic music and brilliant vector-based combat that just draw you in. Very immersive, very fun, very addicting, and by far the best ship builder in any space game I've ever played. The ship builder and sharing tools are really the highlights of the game.

What there is to do:
-Build ships from scratch
-Fly ships in open 2D space
-explore procedurally generated content (As with all games that rely on procedurally generated content, the wow factor goes away pretty fast. Thankfully, this isn't what the game relies on to stay fun)
-Unlock new ship pieces and build better ships out of the scrap of your defeated foes.
-Build a factory and begin constructing a fleet
- Battle fleets made by other players at hotly contested wormholes (There is no multiplayer, but the AI is VERY good and it pilots the fleets that players themselves upload. It priotizes the fleets made by steam friends)
-Enter the wormhole to upload your fleet
-share ship.lua files with friends and pit them in 1v1 battle in tournament mode to see who can make the best ship.
-7 playable factions

That's about it. One last note, it seems that the developer is pretty much done with the game. There haven't been any major patches since the launch and the forum activity has died down quite a bit, but I believe the last thing that's being set up for this game is compatibility with steam workshop so that all future content will come from the game's players rather than the devs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198096889560', 'num_games_owned': 514, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 3343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1814, 'last_played': 1561599140}
review:
极其高的自由度，十分丰富的游戏方式以及大量的可选种族（7种可选）让这个游戏变得十分耐玩。
   同时，玩家可以通过向虫洞内投放自己的复制品来入侵其他玩家的游戏，当然，这个过程是随机而且不可控的，这点很遗憾。
   更为遗憾的是国内目前玩家不多(因为没有汉化)，也组织不起来来场舰船大赛什么的（游戏内自带的模拟战可以实现大量舰船以1对1的模式进行擂台赛）。
   游戏在前期积累时期有些浪费时间，同时后期装备研究完了规模也到8000了会觉得没意思，当然，这时候对舰船的设计或许就是玩点了，或者玩家可以换一个种族再来一遍从小船到大船的过程（击败其他可选种族空间站 工业舰可以解锁）。
   7个可选种族都各具特色，玩法完全不一样，也就是说最次玩家也可以体验七遍不同的游戏方式。
   虽然各个种族稍微有些不太平衡，但是玩家独特的设计可以挽回一些劣势（红色那个种族就算了吧...）。
   最后，其他玩家想试试自己舰船设计的可以来找我，可以把自己的舰船设计存档给我，也可以向我要我的设计图，我一直期待着能够凑上足够的参赛者来一次国内的舰船大赛。

author: {'steamid': '76561198139641420', 'num_games_owned': 107, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 4227, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3055, 'last_played': 1439536851}
review:
If you like construction and customization, building a fleet of ships, leading your fleet into huge battles with other players' fleets for the sake of expanding your galactic empire, buy this game.

Don't let the 2d vector graphics throw you off. Reassembly is a relaxing game with a great soundtrack, infinite creativity, and great battles.

Several different factions, all with a different selection of weapons and hull blocks, gives much more replayability and keeps the gameplay from getting repetetive. The real fun is the ship building, though. Test your ships in simulated battles against other players' designs, and then use them in the game.

Basically if you ever dreamed of building and commanding a fleet of spaceships, you will love this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046229246', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 21374, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15169, 'last_played': 1663883476}
review:
Remember those little fridge magnets you used to play with pretending they were space ships? That's this game, but better.

Of all the space, building, sandbox, and customizable games I've played, this one is way up in my top favorites. For those who love to be creative, this game is a must-get.

PROS:
+ Full customization of ships and stations, shape by shape. This is a huge plus for those who love to build things from the ground-up.
+ Ship building is very well structured and stable. Rarely are there frustrating moments where blocks don't do what I want.
+ Semi-open world (the world loops, but you can travel to new maps too.)
+ Nice graphics & well-built. Nothing too fancy, but still fitting. This game isn't too demanding in general, in terms of hardware.
+ Easy to get the hang of. It doesn't take too long to figure things out.
+ Forgiving gameplay. If you die, you lose all your resources that you were carrying, but if you're nearby enough, you might be able to rush back to pick it up.
 CONS:
- Frustrating at times. There will be times when you have those "BS" moments, and indeed, it gets rather annoying sometimes.
- Trial-by-fire learning curve. I advise against going to the center of the map until you're at max build limit...
- Full customization. For those who aren't able to commit to building your entire ship, there are only a few pre-made ships available at the start. Again, for me, this is still a Pro, but it depends on what games you're into.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027792321', 'num_games_owned': 287, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3375, 'last_played': 1624059775}
review:
Where to start-

Reassembly is a top down 2D action spaceship building/ combat game. Sadly thats all it is though. This does not mean the game doesnt have some fun in it! You can encounter other players ships and send your fleet out for others to find. You will fly through space collecting resources and fighting other ships. It reminds me alot of first stage of SPORE. Ships out and about everywhere, collecting to power up.... Then some behemoth comes along and kills everyone. 

Pros-
- Easy to use builder. Doesnt take long to build ships.
- Decent combat. Sometimes the AI is wonky but all in all good.
- Huge areas to explore. Though after a couple times it feels the same.
- Neat factions each with their own strengths, except 3. Faction 3 is wet tissue paper hanging on toothpicks. Dont hit a rock too hard or bye bye ship.
- Good ship physics. How you build your ship completely affects the way it moves. Only complaint here is the seemingly never ending drift.
- General fun gathering. If you like the first stage of the game SPORE you will enjoy this.

Cons-
- Ship building is somewhat limited. You cant make really huge ships. This is limited by the max 8000P also once they reach a certain size the ether have no speed or no guns.
- Combat is decent but thats all there is to the game. Collect, size up, fight.
- Agents. I love the fact I find other peoples ships, I dont love that sometimes I run into massive fleet 10 mins in that destroys me so hard space rips a new black hole!!
- Some factions are unbalanced. Faction 3 is so soft on the hull that most my deaths came from hitting something too hard. I know it says hard mode but come on now tissue paper is not hull material. Faction 1 and 2 have the most building options. 4 can become really strong really fast. Like cut ships in half kinda strong. After playing all the factions I find 3, 4, 5, 6, 7 left me feeling let down. They didnt have as much to work with as 1 and 2 or were just 1 trick gimmick factions.
-Not all factions are playable. While you can mod to make them so, they are incomplete. I would love to see the borg like faction become playable or the plant type.
-Nothing but combat. I already mentioned this but it really is the biggest issue. Litterally all you do is collect, size up, fight, repeat. The game needs something.

All in all id say 4/5 stars. Sure it has alot of downs but that did not stop me from spending 40 hours surfing the stars. I recommend this to anyone who loved the first level of SPORE. If you liked that you will like this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146413967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6443, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2454, 'last_played': 1628118791}
review:
This game is just too addicting! I can't seem to get enough!

Reveiw:
This game is basically Space engineers on Steroids. Where you design a ship and die a lot of times ( if you're me) or succeed greatly and gain resources and currency to spend on your upgrades and your ship. The ships are completely buildable and you have a large selection of guns to choose from and use (or abuse) on your ship. The map is randomly generated and people are able to upload there fleet of destroyers to your world in the form of agents. These agents are few in number and provide a challenge when you have made your ship so overpowered to the point where you raze other small ships. You can also hire and build allies, and there isn't much of a penalty for death.

11/10 would die 1,000,000 times and kill everything again

author: {'steamid': '76561198008174967', 'num_games_owned': 1272, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 3662, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3386, 'last_played': 1677880742}

review: Very good game, I've played around 500 hours of it and it is still fun. At first everything will kill you, but later almost nothing stands a chance besides agents. A lot of diversity in the different factions. Every faction presents a new way to play, and a new goal to reach. Very easy to learn, very hard not to get blown up by bigger ships and not crash into random things. Only problem I have found in the game is the indestructible faction 1 station cores that sometimes agents are made of. 9 out of 10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198210178768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 155444, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12631, 'last_played': 1710462954}
review:
I guess I should update this review since it was so long ago. It's now almost 10 years since I made the original review and I have over 2,500 hours in the game.

[b]Why do I like Reassembly so much?[/b]
The base campaign is pretty simple and easy to complete. Where have all these hours come from with a tiny indie game?

Basically Reassembly is an engine that allows you to create what you want.

[b]Is the campaign too easy?[/b] - Make it harder by adding your own ships, more agents, or mods.
[b]Tired of the main faction?[/b] - There's six other factions to try out and each has it's own challenges. 
[b]Tired of the vanilla factions?[/b] - There's about 1,000 other factions people have made in the workshop.
[b]Still not happy with how things play?[/b] - Make your own mod and have it play the way you like.
[b]Wish there was more interaction with other player's design?[/b] - Try participating in tournament events, which we do a few times each year.
[b]Tired of building flat 2D ships with a set structure?[/b] - The game allows you to 'stack' blocks to create new design challenges.
[b]Still not done with that?[/b] - Take stuff you previously made and find ways to make it way better now that you know more building tricks.

^ This is how you get 2,500 hours out of a $15 indie game I bought 10 years ago.
10 years from now, I'll probably still be messing with Reassembly as long as I can find a computer to run it on. ... And you know what? The graphics will still be fine because it's all vectors.

Cheers  :D

============
Have a new idea for a ship.
Build it.
Make it better.
Test it.
Make it better.
Fly it around, shoot stuff, build a fleet and commit genocide.

It's now 5:00 am and I'm not sure what day it is.   .... but I have a new idea for a ship

author: {'steamid': '76561198021618539', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 14247, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10769, 'last_played': 1652883468}
review:
선체, 무기, 엔진 등등 모든 부품을 하나부터 열까지 직접 배치해서 자기만의 함선을 제작해서 싸우는... 아마 플래쉬 게임 중에 이와 비슷한 컨셉의 게임을 해 본 기억이 있을 겁니다. 스팀에도 '캡틴 포에버' 라고 비슷한 스타일의 게임이 있네요.
한번 빠지면 시간 가는 줄 모르고 자기 함선 만지작대는데 열중하게 됩니다. 99% 커스터마이징이 귀찮은 분은 그저 고통스러우실듯

온라인 플레이는 지원하지 않지만 인게임 맵 여기저기에 존재하는 '웜홀'을 통해 온라인으로 자기 함선을 업로드하여 간접적으로 다른 플레이어가 내 함대하고 맞닥뜨리게 할 수 있고, 반대도 가능합니다.

밸런스가 영 뒤죽박죽이지만 스팀 창작마당에 꾸준히 올라오는 유저 모드를 사용하거나, 아니면 자기가 직접 부품들의 스펙을 바꿔 플레이 할 수 있습니다. 리셈블리 공식 홈페이지에 직접 모딩하는 방법도 친절히 설명되어있으니 참고하면 도움이 될 겁니다. 영어지만요(...)
* 당연하겠지만 모드가 적용된 함선들은 업로드가 불가능합니다.

어차피 자작 함선으로 자딸치는게 가장 큰 비중을 차지하는 게임이고, 각 팩션 별로 나름 개성있는 부품체계를 갖춰서 컨셉 플레이 용도로는 그만입니다. 외관상으로 그럴듯하게 꾸미는건 캡틴 포에버보다 이쪽이 더 낫다는 느낌이네요.




단지 가격이 약간 비싼 느낌이고( 필자는 이미 백수십시간 넘게 즐겨서 상관 없지만 ), 출시된지 1년이 지난 지금도 드물게 업데이트가 됩니다만, 말그대로 정말 드물게 업데이트를 합니다. 구매하기 전에 이 게임이 사후관리를 누구도 보장할 수 없는 '인디게임' 이라는 걸 꼭 염두에 두셨으면 합니다.

review: Honestly one of the flat out coolest games I've ever played. The whole feel of the game, how it's organic yet futuristic and simple yet extremely complex is just awesome to me. It's a game that invites you to show off your creativity and ingenuity, and really makes you proud of your progress and what you've achieved no matter how far into the game you are, even if you're already been there in a previous save. Easy to learn, hard (but extremely fun) to master. Well worth the 15 bucks, would highly recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970533652', 'num_games_owned': 513, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1944, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 997, 'last_played': 1666724181}
review:
This one is pretty original and addictive.

Its a 2D space shooter with RPG / progression elements.

The original part is that the RPG elements are all in the design of your ship.  You'll progress by designing better shaped and more capable craft as you go, and the designing mode itself is a lot of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198017871005', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 3052, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2495, 'last_played': 1664744421}
review:
I like this game, but it gets stale very quickly and the developer didn't deliver on the promises made during early access.  The game is exactly the same as it was when it came out on Steam, with the only major addition being a "tournament" mode where you plop a couple ships into a ladder to see which one wins out.

The aesthetic is interesting, but ultimately the actual game is shallow.  Most of the gameplay comes from designing your ship and seeing how it fares in combat, but the combat is doesn't have strategic depth other than ramming or kiting.  Your design slowly moves away from what you'd call an actual spaceship and more towards a geometric shape with internal engines.  A basic square filled with as many weapons and shields as possible is simply better than trying to create anything that's actually interesting.  Ship combat, therefore, devolves into a blob of shields mounted on a square careening through space and slamming into other blobs of shields in an orgy of lasers and missiles.  It looks nice, but carefully designing a ship isn't worth the effort.

The design system is simple and easy to understand, but in practice it just falls flat.

The "living world" is also not really what you'd expect.  Capturing territory across the galaxy becomes an exercise in Exterminatus from Warhammer 40,000.  You bring as many ships as possible and cleanse every single enemy ship from an area of the map, which then switches colour to your faction.  That's it.  You don't get any resources, your own ships don't start to spawn there, not even a message appears on screen.  A part of the map changes colour, and you move on to the next area.  Eventually this devolves into chasing one tiny little gnat of a ship that can't even hurt you across your territory because it keeps reclaiming tiles.  It's tedious.

Don't get me wrong, I liked this game, but it is very shallow and the replayability just isn't there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088214485', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 4930, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2222, 'last_played': 1582444741}

author: {'steamid': '76561197998391180', 'num_games_owned': 3439, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 2898, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1127, 'last_played': 1689102115}
review:
Creativity in video games has always been a standard. How do you beat this next boss? How do you navigate past this obstacle? In the past, the solution usually had a few different answers, but today the answers offered really do seem endless. Reassembly demostrates this by placing you in a gigantic galactic sandbox. You will start as the little fish, and work your way into becoming a devastating war-machine. Do you prefer anti-matter cannons, or a nice simple plasma beam? Maybe you will swarm the enemies with missiles and drones. Maybe even all of the above! Eventually you will also get the opportunity to design and produce your own fleet with a factory attachment. Each ship can be given a “child order” in which they will spawn their own new ships as long as they too have a factory attached. A war-machine and a loving mother? Oh the duality of man… Er, woman… Err… Spaceship. This isn’t going well. Anyways, let’s take a closer look at Reassembly.

Upon killing an enemy ship you will start to gain “R” or resources, which can then be traded in for “C” (currency). The currency is then used to buy new parts that can be used in any new ship design, this means you will probably redesign your ships fairly regularly to keep up with the latest, greatest weapons in attempts to conquer bigger threats. Your mothership has a “P” limit, I assume P is for power, which can be upgraded with the currency. The power limit of any ship designs constructed will translate to the resource cost once you eventually unlock the factory. While the basics can take a while to master due to the needlessly abbreviated names, eventually your mother-ship will be ready to take on anything. You will scoot around repairing damaged stations, which are actually destroyed by your enemies in real time! There are 7 factions, which means 6 different races to destroy! While you might enjoy feeding on their little guys, stay on your guard because there is almost always a bigger fish. Then again, it might be worth the risk because destroying one of the gigantic capital ships among their allied swarm is extremely thrilling!

Maintaining control of an entire galaxy is tough work though, and opposing factions aren’t the only ones out to ruin your rampage. Agent fleets, which are created and uploaded by other users (via wormholes) will relentlessly hunt down and destroy your spawning stations. When you finally find your way back to try and repair it, prepare for one hell of a fight. Flight and weapons are wonderfully dynamic, both in combat and out. Navigating an asteroid field takes a lot of foresight, unless you just have a set of lasers mounted to burn through anything that gets in your way. Some weapons are able to follow your cursor, while others are mounted firmly to the ship. Finding the best combination for your race, fleet, and strategy is absolutely imperative. Each of the seven races offers a completely unique set of parts for their ships so even after you’ve cleaned up the galaxy as one team, there is still tons of incentive to go back and try the others. The AI is pretty intelligent as well. You won’t see a drone ship (yours or the enemy’s) rush into the fray, and even the combat fighters know when it’s time to retreat.

There is very little criticism I’m able to find for Reassembly. It does lack a story, and the level generation seems completely random which doesn’t lead to much strategy regarding which colored enemies to go after until later in the game when territories have more or less been established. Overall, I found Reassembly to be an endlessly replayable treat, with a learning curve much higher than one would perceive at first glance. There are so many little touches that put this game over the top, such as the ship building battle simulator, in which you can test your newly constructed ship against enemies of around the same cost. This helps immensely with knowing how the AI will handle the many ships you spawn for it. Paired with the amazing construction, and as many galaxies as there are wormholes to crawl through (read: ENDLESS) this game is a fantastic indie gem that has truly blessed my library. Big thanks to Anisoptera Games and Indie Voyage for the review copy, this game is a jump away from absolute perfection. Fantastic work!

Gameplay:

    Controls- 9/10
    Fun Factor- 10/10
    Difficulty- 9/10
    Replayability- 10/10
    Innovation- 9/10

Aesthetic:

    Graphics- 9/10
    Music- 7/10
    Sound FX- 8/10
    Story/Lore- 5/10
    Level Design- 6/10

Final Score: 84/100 for fun factor, replayability, and graphics.
Summary: A gorgeous space-sandbox which allows you to design your own fleet and strategy.
Verdict: Reassembly will please anyone with an eye for construction and customization.

Gameplay/Review video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GO65vyQ9IVQ
Full text/photo review: http://www.indiegamebundles.com/review-reassembly/

author: {'steamid': '76561197974575672', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 8754, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4013, 'last_played': 1698889069}
review:
This game is a lot of fun.  I still play it on occasion.  I have played all of the races to their max, and I still find some fun stuff to do.  

You build your ship out of geometric shapes and weaponry, and can build a fleet of your own ships.  As you build ships / stations, the randomly generated galaxy will start to incorporate them.  As far as I can tell, this works across save files as well.  I built a great ship with one race that was pretty much unstoppable and it showed up when I was playing another race as an agent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064584233', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 4948, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2799, 'last_played': 1470473735}
review:
I made a ship that's also a giant mouth, with plasma guns on the teeth. I used it to conquer a huge swathe of the galaxy, devouring all who crossed my path. None could stop me. Then I met my match. A huge, blocky warship covered in enormous plasma cannons. So I upgraded my ship. I went up to the level of battlecruiser. But I still couldn't destroy it.

Eventually, after much fighting, I worked out that the command module was vulnerable at the back. I downgraded to a tiny corvette and flew up behind it. I started firing my weapons, staying out of range of the heavy plasma cannons. My beams gnawed away as the other battleships approached. Then I got through the armour. I smashed the command pod.

I had won.

So yeah, it's pretty good.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002688923', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 35, 'playtime_forever': 1256, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 991, 'last_played': 1599188371}

author: {'steamid': '76561198020162488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 113108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13757, 'last_played': 1710202698}
review:
Simply put, this game is amazeballs! Seriously, buy this game. I would never have imagined someone making something like this or me going apeshit over it and yet here it is; At it's core just a handful of basic ideas, geometric building blocks, and one giant helping of awesome-sauce slathered on top to drown the whole thing in.

Here's what to expect:

1. A Procedurally generated space sandbox so the game is literally new every time you start a new game.
2. A palette of glowing geometric blocks with which to build your epic spaceship/station heart out.
3. Your own fleet lovingly mouse-crafted by you from one of 7 factions unlockable by playing the game and dominating your enemies.
4. 100s of stock ships from the 12 (or 13?) distinct in-game factions populating your space-box (that's "space sandbox" for those of you catching up).
5. One of my own ships showing up in your space-box bent on dominating your universe via the "Wormhole" system that allows AI controlled versions of other Reassembly player's ships to appear as "Agents" and lay down some good ol' fashioned obliteration on your ass.
6. Out of control radiant geometric space-plants growing on  nearby asteroid fields that SEEM to not pose a serious threat compared to the other guys with plasma-cannons and burst-lasers but just wait....just wait...
7. Moddable factions (currently in beta) where you, yes YOU! can create your own block palette, ships, and other faction goodies to inject into your game or upload to the Steam Workshop and let others play with your wonderful (or evil...) creations.
8. An awesome in-game soundtrack by recording artist Peaks.
9. Hours to fly by as you have an amazing time playing one of the greatest games there ever was or is or will be in this dimension or the other infinity of them. Seriously, buy this game. 

What not to Expect:

1. True synchronous multiplayer....sorry folks, this doesn't seem to be a thing in Reassembly but who knows about the future? *wink wink Arthur wink wink*
2. Boredom. In fact, kiss that asshole goodbye because Reassembly will be filling his usual spot from now on.
3. Buyer's Remorse. "This game is good. This is game is very good." - Everyone

author: {'steamid': '76561198015740903', 'num_games_owned': 210, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 24934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3375, 'last_played': 1509951192}
review:
This is THE definitive lego game for lovers of space and starships.
       It always surprises me when developers are able to boil the concept of 'fun' down to such a simple, gratifying level. And that is exactly what you get with this game; an intuitive fleet building experience where the fun doesn't stop when you hit the building menues. 
       I'd argue it starts there. Though admittedly half or so of my game-time was spent afk (as with most games I play), I have spent roughly 20 hours building ships, and maybe 5 actually cruising around. The 'tournament' style mode you can throw any ship you've been building into is incredibly rewarding, and oddly relaxing. Sitting back and watching the Dreadnaught you've spent an hour on go ripping through other people's lovingly crafted creations is a great system that both allows you to test out your ship against a variety of other players' designs, and serves as eye candy to the nth degree.
   
       The game has a concept of 'agent' fleets, in which a fleet designed by other players invades your world. There is a peculiar feeling I get from this game that stems from this idea, and not even necessarily when I'm playing it. The fact that some poor player will at some point accidentaly have a run in with my fine tuned, massive killing machines gives me a sadistic pleasure that I would say is almost entirely unique to this game.

A gem of a game for people of all ages, and now that it has modding support added, who knows what can come out of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025582931', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 3823, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1344, 'last_played': 1603526361}
review: It has the most beautiful, sweet, calm, serene, scenic, twirling death scenes and the best feature a top down space shooter can have, build your ship out of parts available using a gradual point buy. Early game learning curve is a little ugly but they give enough info that you can Seuss it out. I can see this game going somewhere.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075360983', 'num_games_owned': 165, 'num_reviews': 57, 'playtime_forever': 1002, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 176, 'last_played': 1616196115}
review:
Dans Reassembly, il y a tout ce qu'on aime dans un jeu d'exploration spaciale...

C'est beau, c'est très fluide, c'est coloré, c'est gigantesque ! 

On commence basiquement avec un vaisseau très limité en équipement, puis en dégommant les petits vaisseaux qui trainent on évolue gentillement, on se fixe des objectifs sans s'ennuyer. Le monde est vaste, les ennemis divers et les factions féroces. Une fois atteint les 8000P de vaisseau, là on prend plaisir à optimiser son escadrille !

 [b]Points positifs : [/b]
[list]
[*] La musique, vraiment dans le thème (ma chériiiiiiiiiie) et entrainante ! 

[*] Les graphismes:  somptueux, on ne peut pas rêver mieux pour ce genre de jeux. Lorsque le jeu peine à afficher les 300 vaisseaux, 4000 missiles et 2000 drones sur l'écran, il baisse la vitesse du jeu sans jamais sacrifier le framerate: un gros point agréable!

[*] Les factions : on les pense similaires mais elles ont toutes des points forts et des points faibles. Du générateur de bouclier taille XL en passant par le Missile nucléaire jusqu'aux épées laser devastatrices à courte portée...

[*] La personnalisation : même si certains prérequis demeurent (les propulseurs doivent être répartis uniformément dans chaque direction pour avoir un vaisseau assez mobile), à vous de créer le vaisseau qui vous semble le plus efficace et le plus resistant. On passe d'abord aux vaisseaux cubiques pour aller vers des formes plus variées, souvent optimisées pour le combat selon nos préférences.

[*]La possibilité de tester vos vaisseaux en 1v1, l'IA du jeu s'en occupe mais étant bien developpée parfois on est scotché quant aux resultats. Ce n'est pas le plus gros qui l'emporte (pas tout le temps) !
[/list]
 [b]Points négatifs : [/b]
[list]

[*] Certaines factions rencontrées en jeu ne sont pas (encore?) jouables... C'est dommage on aimerait bien essayer!

[*] Le multijoueur n'existe pas encore (ou pas trouvé..). Pour l'instant, votre flotte est sauvegardée sur les serveurs et vous rencontrez aléatoirement dans votre galaxie la flotte d'un autre mais toujours contrôlée par l'ordinateur...

[*] L'équilibrage entre les factions est à mon goût encore à travailler... Surtout la faction rouge-orangée qui malgré un arsenal dévastateur n'a aucun moyen de protection et croyez moi, même les plus gros vaisseaux sont facilement détruits...

[/list]

Je vous recommande vivement ce jeu. Car étant en développement ça ne peut que s'améliorer et les idées sont là.

L'évaluation est donc susceptible d'être modifiée.

author: {'steamid': '76561198115092745', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 4718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2410, 'last_played': 1589375758}
review:
Ich liebe dieses Spiel! Es macht extrem viel Spass mit verschiedenen Schiffsdesigns und Fraktionen rumzuspielen. 
Da man sieben verschiedene Fraktionen , die sich alle anders spielen ( z.t. sogar extrem unterschiedlich ) und eine enorme Gestaltungsfreiheit hat sind auch viele Spielstunden rauszukriegen. Ich habe jetzt 30 Stunden gespielt und das Gefühl die Anzahl der Möglichkeiten noch nicht annähernd ausgeschöpft zu haben.
Es ist auch möglich eigene Schiffe ,die man konstruiert hat, in seiner Flotte mitzuführen um noch mehr Feuerkraft zu haben.
Die Stationen, die man eingenommen hat bauen auch neue Schiffe, die auch Spielerdesigns sein können, was dazu führt, dass sich die Welt sehr lebendig anfühlt. Die Flotten anderer Spieler, die oft schwer zu besiegen sind können allerdings auch problematisch sein, falls es nicht gelingt ihnen zu entkommen solang man noch nicht stark genug ist sie zu zerstören. Das passiert aber nicht häufig und die Spielerflotten sind später im Spiel eine wilkommene Ablenkung wenn man sonst herümfliegen und alles zerstören könnte. (Das macht aber auch wirklich Spass)
Riesige Raumschlachten mit vielen Schiffen, die wirklich chaotisch und lebendig aussehen trüben den Spielspass auch nicht gerade.

Das Spiel läuft sogar in grösseren Schlachten recht flüssig, dabei ist mein PC nicht sehr gut. 

Ist die 15 € meiner Meinung nacht wirklich wert.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093651616', 'num_games_owned': 433, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 733, 'last_played': 1578121016}
review:
I have to say that before I purchases this game, I was kind of nervous about how it would be, though it had some really good reviews. I soon found out that those reviews lived up to the positive nature.

Starting out as a single faction to pick, and a basic little ship, you start out a bit causious, trying to gather resources to build your ship up and try to take control of the map with a fleet of your own design along side you.

I have to say that one thing that really impressed me is how optimized this game really is. It might seem like the simple nature of just polygons and other shapes would run smooth, but the effects and lighting that can take place during a large battle between many ships can cause your system to lag. Surprisingly though, it takes several hundred ships in that battle before it really starts to take any effect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198161744481', 'num_games_owned': 221, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 4540, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1594, 'last_played': 1663900963}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030688533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 3321, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2038, 'last_played': 1701713981}
review:
Bon, un petit commentaire en français afin que les francophones puissent s'intersser au jeu car il en vaut rééllement la peine. 

Déjà le jeu est beau. Magnifique, splendide. Sur Mac le rendu est superbe. Sans parler de l'OST qui est à tomber et qui met vraiment dans une super ambiance.

Mais bon, c'est beau machin machin, mais qu'en est-il du gameplay ?

Reassembly est un jeu où l'on contrôle son vaisseau spatial. Ce vaisseau est modiafiable et améliorable grâce à des pièces d'armes, de propulsion et j'en passe. Et toutes ces pièces sont différentes en fonction des factions qui s'élévent au nombre de 7. Car une des forces de Reassembly réside dans la personnalisation.

Votre but va être à la fois de controler un espace plus grand sur la carte et d'avoir un meilleur vaisseau au fur et mesure du jeu. Il faudra donc jongler entre vous et votre faction.
Reassembly s'avère surprenant dans l'intensité de certaines batailles spatiales et dans la physique du jeu. Reassembly dispose d'une physique superbe ce qui oblige a faire des modifications necessaires sur le vaisseau (Ex: si vous n'avez pas de système de propulsion sur les cotés de votre navire, il ne pourra qu'aller en ligne droite). Cala peut paraître comme un détail mais vous comprendrez en y jouant.

Un petit coup de gueule : le jeu n'est qu'en anglais (pour l'instant !) ce qui rend le tutoriel assez complexe au début, mais les mécaniques s'assimilent au fil du jeu.

J'avais acheté Reassembly sur un gros coup de tête, et bien je ne suis pas déçu et si vous hésitez, n'hésitez plus et foncez. Le jeu est sorti il y a deux mois, il y a eu une MàJ en Mars et il y en a une de prévu en Avril. Autant dire que le jeu s'avère TRES prometteur.

Amusez vous bien !

----------

EDIT :

Un an plus tard...

Reassambly est devenu une perle. Le jeu n'a plus rien à prouver.
Il a été rendu compatible avec le workshop ce qui l'a rendu encore plus diversifié.
De nouvelles armes et pieces de vaisseaux sont apparus laissant place a de nouvelles stratégies de batailles. Un grand bravo et merci aux Developpeurs.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046836741', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 32847, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 16, 'playtime_at_review': 10842, 'last_played': 1712302569}
review:
This games has essentially redefined the "build your own spaceship" kind of games. Sure, it's only 2D - but that gives the modding commuity much more room to push the boundaries! In terms of goals there are basically three:

Destroy all hostiles (thus stay alive)
Design awesome custom ships
Have a relaxing cruise through space to the games sweet soundtrack.

In a bit more detail though; some people dislike the deliberate inaccuracy with space physics, but I think it helps to simplify the playing and strategising. Having blocks with different features (such as ncreasing thrust/torque, beam weapons, cannons, missiles, resource generators) the creative potential is only really limited by the block limit and the RAM of your PC (I play this on a 8GB RAM laptop and it works OK, but best results come from higher RAM).

All in all, I cannot praise this game enough!

author: {'steamid': '76561198049078901', 'num_games_owned': 692, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2956, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1951, 'last_played': 1556497854}
review:
[i]It's Reassembly:
Customizable Spaceships,
Maybe look at guides.[/i]

   Reassembly is an interesting 2D sandboxy game where, simply put, you make spaceships out of varying sets of shapes and modules in an attempt to devour all other living things in the galaxy and unleash an age of your own reign. Or you could just get the second playable faction and make giant solar panel stations. Doing that also works.
   Anyway, I would suggest playing Reassembly if you like to create pretty things, functional things, or just spacey things in general. I personally like it for the large amount of customization which can be expanded even further with (apparently) easy modding that I have yet to dip my toes into.
   One of the few downsides I can think of is the fact that the various "factions" are limited to specific sets of blocks instead of it being all blocks at once, but that kind of makes it more balanced, otherwise you would end up having giant solar panel stations with nuke all over them.

As an added note about the last line of that haiku, I would suggest reading through some guides if you're having trouble at first. Unless it's just really not your cup of tea, it will probably get fun eventually.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964696375', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 2534, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2330, 'last_played': 1487295121}
review:
Extreamly addicting and fun game.  The ship designing system and balance is brilliant, as is the economy and ship-reproduction system.  Good for about 40 hours of intense gaming. WOW.

My only gripe is that after playing the game as the starter race for about 40 hours and hitting the part cap, I hit a wall because I got the feeling I'd expereinced everything in the game.  In my opinion, the other races and the "clean out the entire universe" tasks aren't as compelling as the development of increasingly complex and dangerous ships as you "level up".  The honeymoon ends once you hit the part cap. 

In my opinion, if there were no part cap, i would probably play this forever making like deathstars at some point.

My hat is off to the developers, they have accomplished something really impressive with reassembly.  I hope that it inspires developers everywhere in the future.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000425817', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 5041, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3028, 'last_played': 1489440286}
review:
I love this game. Spent hours, no days building and optimizing spaceship designs. This is a designer's game.

Pros:
-The controls are flexable so you can fly however you want, a very welcome feature in these top down 2D games.
-The attention to detail in physics is incredible, e.g. if your ship has no off-axis thrusters, it turns really slowly.
-Open ended - no one strategy to dominate. You can go for speed, armor, shields, range, or build cost. Or you can just be a farmer or a gatherer.
-Multiple races - just when you think you've optimized a ship series for a particular race, you can play a different race with different abilities and different parts!
-Really pretty
-Self-building ships: the trouble with other building games (e.g. StarMade) is that you always have to rebuild your ship after a battle. In this game you don't worry about that, although there are design strategies for having your ship regenerate faster.
-Good combat AI, so you're not frustrated with the AI pilots being idiotic which breaks many other games.
-Ability to customize the build sequence of allied ships and stations

Would like to see:
Fleet vs fleet battles with the asynchronous mulitplayer! There are ways to do this with the sandbox but it's not very accessible.
Better (maybe customizable) combat AI: e.g. turning the ship to hide damaged armor or shields from enemy fire while it regenerates, or maybe being able to specify a preferred range of engagement.
Better non-combat AI: Having AI ships being more exploratory would be nice, otherwise they exhaust their local resources and just end up sitting around.

My dream is to build an agent fleet that can go into someone else's universe, replicate like crazy and be hugely successful, and completely take it over. Muhahahaha.

review:
Reassembly. 

A game about building spaceships and fighting against AIs In a open galaxy.

You can design your own ships completely form scratch out of different parts.

There are 7 playable factions each with different parts to use.

If you like captain forever you will almost certainly like Reassembly.

You can collect resources from plants and build a fleetof your own to fight along side you.

Definatly worth buying!

author: {'steamid': '76561198213602552', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 3448, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2207, 'last_played': 1684629575}

author: {'steamid': '76561198041108753', 'num_games_owned': 312, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 16588, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4073, 'last_played': 1662812445}
review:
Sometimes, two children building spaceships out of LEGO will be in the same room and without adult supervision. They will probably start by dogfighting their plastic creations, but sooner or later they will be taking turns to throw each spaceship into the other. This is the game of those models.

Reassembly's ship creation is simple but pretty intricate in its outcome - you strap 2D weapons, components, inert hull pieces and engines to your command module until you're happy with the result. Ships can be any size, shape, scale (ships can be worth 50 points or 8000), tactical role and degree of effectiveness. You could build the Serenity, a Star Destroyer, a butterfly, a cartoon house with drone launchers in the windows, a space station shaped like Dover Castle or even a sniper rifle with a spinal death weapon for the barrel and a point defence laser for the trigger.

At any time during the customisation you can press the 'test' button, and the AI will fly the ship against available stock designs in a 1v1 arena battle. You can also use the tournament game mode to watch battles between selected designs from any of your save files, any of your friends' save files and any .lua files someone has shared elsewhere on the internet. The devs run occasional open tournaments for ship designs, as do some youtubers.

Single player is utterly devoid of story, it's basically a sandbox galaxy in which various mutually hostile factions hold territory. Kill things and provide R (the production resource) to your factory ships to gain C (research resource). Use C to increase your ship's build limit and unlock new components to play with, or to hire friendly ships to follow you around. Install a factory on your ship to be able to spend R on your custom escort ships, which you can release for more C. Conquer and comsume the galaxy, find a wormhole, travel to the next galaxy and start over. The visuals are pretty nice, the opposing factions are diverse and the fact that your escort ships are ones you yourself have designed makes the campaign feel more exclusive and personal in a 4X-ey sort fo way.

The 7 playable factions generally handle differently, which adds some replayability. Some factions have diamond or rhombus hull pieces, changing their look and design priorities. there's a faction with really cheap shield generators and sniper cannons that can spawn resource-generating space-plants, there's a faction with cheap high-damage weapons and deadly beam drones but very little effective armour, there's a faction whose only direct weapon is a spinal plasma launcher you build by stacking modular components on top of each other. There's one faction that gets nuke launchers and melee spikes.

On the downside though, some of the factions get their playstyle from a lack of versatlity and a poor choice of components. It's pretty demoralising to look at a new faction's full array of hardware and think 'is this it?' Tournaments can be dominated by Faction 4 (the modular plasma cannon one) and by 'spinny ships' (that exploit the AI's ability to lead targets, making them impossible to hit), the music is good but can be intrusive and gets repetitive after the first dozen hours or so. The campaign has almost no ships bigger than 3000P, meaning a player with the cap of 8000P gets to stomp everything with little effort or interesting events. They are small complaints but they do add up sometimes.

To finish, I'll say that Rassembly holds its players' attention not with a scripted or even emergent narrative, or with a great challenge, but with the promise of having something to tinker with. Working out the strengths of each weapon or design, using those extra 200P to give your flagship a little more punch, and reverse-engineering a design you saw on youtube that one time, are what contributes to an addictive and engaging experience that's well worth the £11 it asks for.

review: This is a fun game that can be played casually while still offering some intense moments. The choice of different factions offers some degree of gameplay balancing: for a difficult play choose race 2, or for easier gameplay, race 4. Tons of fun building and testing my creations against community builds and those of my friends, and when you unleash an armada of ships through a wormhole you will chuckle right up to the point that you run into someone elses death fleet and get hammered. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198059561891', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 416, 'playtime_forever': 155, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 155, 'last_played': 1428434816}
review:
Reassembly puts you in command of not only one ship but an entire fleet of customizable and player made ships. 
The beauty of Reassembly lies in its freedom. From experimenting with ships to exploring the galaxy, as you pass by gargantuan space battles happening around you. 
However there is some blackholes in the beautiful universe that is Reassembly. Controls and lack of tool tips can make the game a little bit frustrating at times. Experimentation is required to figure what does what. Also combat ends like a flash in pan. Either you or your enemy will usually over power one another and it will end rather quickly. Not to mention the computers pin-point accuracy that simply a human couldn't replicate due to the camera. Leaving all your best laid designs to ruin. Graphically and musically Reassembly hits the mark. With a space themed soundtrack that is enjoyable to listen to and vibrant colors that fill out the galaxy. Reassembly givens you freedom to make what you want and do what you want. Long as you don't mind a little inconvenience here and there.

I made a video review to show off some of the features and gameplay of this game!
https://youtu.be/YfyDepRbQnQ
I hope you enjoy!
Martyr

author: {'steamid': '76561198019355296', 'num_games_owned': 337, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 3984, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 586, 'last_played': 1659141736}
review:
Great game, I'd even go as far as to call it superb. Basically you start as a small ship being part of a faction. You go around collecting resources and fighting enemy ships, bringing the resources back to your base or to motherships to be rewarded C (the "money" currency in the game). C is used to upgrade the max points you can spend on your ship, meaning you can create bigger ships with better guns and upgrades. C is also used to buy new weapons and things like shields you can put on your ships. You can recruit other ships also with C but it's a stupid thing to do since you won't really earn any C if you spend it on getting allies.
So you go around the galaxy, restoring your faction's stations and earning C and resources by doing so, destroying ships and their stations to enlarge your territory, but the enemy factions do the same thing to you. They destroy your stations and your hive ships and as you are expanding your territory in one direction, it's easy to lose your grip in another part of the galaxy meaning you have to upgrade all the ships in your faction as you unlock more total points to spend on ships, otherwise they will be too fragile when the enemies attack your base. You personally customize all the ships in your faction any way you want to, mixing functionality with design or just going flat out functionality with ugly ships.
After a while when you've earned a ton of C, upgrading the total points you can spend on ships, you start to build hive ships which can create new ships. You get to choose 4 ships that you can create but you can replace those ships whenever you want to without replacing the already built ships, meaning you can build 4 ships of a certain type then switch them out and build the next 4 while keeping the ones you already built so you can basically have a whole fleet of all the ships in your faction. This is when the game becomes fun for me because now, you're basically free to do whatever you want to. You started as a drone for your faction and now you have become a moving station, building ships from the resources you and the ships you produced gather for you, growing your fleet larger and larger all the time being able to take on more difficult enemy factions. Or you could just stay as a fighter ship if you're into that, collecting resources for your faction and letting it expand on its own.

author: {'steamid': '76561198046933387', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2306, 'last_played': 1459562995}
review: This game is 1000% authentically fun, no gimmicks, no bull. The concept starts out very simple, but you find yourself in something simplistic becoming rich, detailed and thought provoking. This is a return to better days of gaming, modernized.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079307571', 'num_games_owned': 1549, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 878, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1571950781}
review:
This game is an awesome starship building/destroying sandbox. It is open ended, there are no goals. You build a ship, kill ships, gather resources, unlock parts, raise your ship size limit, build bigger ship, kill bigger ships, build something insane, die, try egain :-D Killing an enemy capital ship unlocks that faction for you and you can use it in your next save.

Graphic style is simple but looks very good. It is colourful and trippy. I would describe it as a space Lego on acid.

Sound design is ok. Nothing mindblowing, nothing bad - it works and doesn't pull your attention too much.

Music is great. It helps you to immerse yourself into this space madness. It will get you into some kind of trance and then you realize, that this game managed to devour your whole evening :-D

If you need story and goals, this is not a game for you. But if you like to build crazy things and test them in combat + you like 2D space combat games, you will love this thing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009384224', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 6248, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3515, 'last_played': 1662575032}
review: The LEGO-style ship-building process that has "realistic" impact on how good your fleet actually is compared to others is addictive. At least to people like me who grew up building LEGO spaceships and always wished that they could actually mass-battle them against each other. The sound track is mesmerizing, I just wish (after 40+ hours) that there would be a few more songs for variety. But it's still far from boring, very inspiring in fact. The graphics are stylishly abstract and big battles are amazingly beautiful. This game really is a treat, and I am glad I backed it on Kickstarter last year. Thank you so much to all the developers, I'll certainly keep playing this for years!

author: {'steamid': '76561197983188657', 'num_games_owned': 876, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 6071, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4802, 'last_played': 1548531804}

author: {'steamid': '76561198086554974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 8318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1279, 'last_played': 1701148347}
review:
The game is fun, and I love the customization. You have to build your ships to match your environment, and play style/skill. The battles are intense, and very frantic at times. 



But then there are agents.



An agent in this game is another player's fleet, uploaded and ugly. The problem with agents is two fold:

a) They are usually better equipped than you are.

b) They actively destroy your stations/territory.



Agents suck. Make it a priority to destroy them. Leave, harvest, min max, eradicate.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072768799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 30775, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 23575, 'last_played': 1697078996}
review:
[h1] This. Beautiful. Game. [/h1]

For those who enjoy having the ability to build literally almost EVERYTHING for yourself, this is very, very, very welcoming to the creative minds out there. Every single aspect of the ship is COMPLETELY up to you, as you build your ship (and soon) fleet; not just build, but evolve.

At first, you might get lost real easily by how the game starts out, dropping you in the middle of the game, letting you get your hands in the thick of it with no real instruction. EXPERIMENT! This game is literally endless, with no real, true penalties to stop you from doing whatever you want. From a few simple polygons, you clump it together slowly, piece by piece, and learn what YOU enjoy, and find to work, and improve off it. Not only that, but this game can conform to the way you wish to play easily, so there is NEVER any one, right way to play. 

Wish to go in hard and heavy, with a giant, bulk-head cruiser? Go ahead, and charge at enemies with a hailstorm of laser beams. Or stay it safe, and strafe your enemies and snipe from afar with powerful missles and energy shots to obliterate the enemy. It is entirely put into the hand of the creator: You. 

I bought this when it was at $30; I would do it again and again. I found it good enough to actually post a review for the FIRST TIME. With a lovely $15 price tag, and with how well sewed this whole game is, based on such a simple concept and turned into something limitless, I could nearly argue it's the best game I've ever played in my life thus far.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049200072', 'num_games_owned': 51, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 124997, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18089, 'last_played': 1609960164}
review:
Reasembly. It is more than a vectored spaceship-building sandbox game. It is a game of infinite possibilities! It is an extrememly addicting game should you have a creative and boundless imagination. With seven highly modifiabe factions to play as, [spoiler] and three more playable factions when modifying the game's cvars.txt [/spoiler], explore an ever-evolving galaxy full of wonders, dangers, and plants [spoiler]that are more than welcome to slice you to ribbons[/spoiler].

[spoiler] You also have access to a sandbox mode, which you can use to create literally any ship.[/spoiler]

[spoiler] Press \ in the main game to access sandbox abilities, too![/spoiler]

Imagine the tidepool of "Spore"'s Cell Stage, combined with the role-playing aspect of "Faster Than Light", and the simple ship-building mechanics from the flash game "Captain Forever", and the theme of the Space Stage of the aformentioned "Spore". This is basically Reassembly in a nutshell. Or is it?

author: {'steamid': '76561197989499070', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 17970, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11800, 'last_played': 1671241837}
review:
This game rocks. It sucked me in completely for a couple of weeks. I'd look up at the clock and think omg it's been 6 hours! I'd go to work the next day on 5 hours sleep. It stirred my gamer blood! The ship building freedom is top notch. You build any kind of ship you want particle by particle and there are lots of smart, handy features in the ship building editor to save time. You can hold down the mouse and drag it across an area to select multiple components or you can just double click one piece and everything attached to it will be selected. 

A quick ship building tip is to just build one side of the ship, say a wing, select all the pieces then hit c to copy. Move the cursor to a blank part of the screen and hit v to paste, then hit m to mirror (to invert the selection). Now you can just attach that perfectly mirrored section onto the opposite side of the ship if you need symmetry like for wings.
Symmetry is also important in placing your thrusters. You are in space so your ship isn't going to stop moving unless it crashes into something...or you put thrusters pointed in the opposite direction to the direction you're traveling in so you can break!
Also each different playable faction has some unique pieces to build with. Sometimes the minor differences aren't obvious, like where pieces don't have as much mass as other factions or they have slightly higher armor, but when you stack all those pieces together into a ship then the net values really make a difference in speed, toughness, or resource carrying capacity. You'll want to look at the stats on the ship pieces closely if you're into ship building.
If you're not into ship building there are premade ships available with each faction that you can use and just modify to your taste.

The game is beautiful to look at and very organic. To me it looks more like the world under a microscope filled with living, evolving organisms than it does a space frontier. Much like organisms, the ships actually create children. You can set a creation queue for yourself once you have a factory as part of your design. But you can also go into command mode by hitting tab and click on an allied vessel that has a factory and drag child designs into their queue so you begin to shape the future of your factions expansion without actually managing the execution. Just hit tab again to go back into pilot mode and go on your way. The allied ship you just programmed will now create what you set for it via the AI. 

Once you've got your perfect fleet together you can find then fly into a wormhole. You will be given an option to follow it or stay. If you stay a parallel version of your fleet will upload to infect another player's galaxy through one of their wormholes while you remain where you're at with your original fleet. I just really wish there was some way of knowing how successful these invasions were, like a scoring system players could access to get some sense of how good your designs were.

The tournament mode doesn't pit you against other players. It just lets you test your own ships against your own designs and a small selection of premade designs. I would love to see a true tournament mode where you download player agents and test your ship against theirs with scoring. The game lacks true player interaction in real time but atleast we can see other player's creations as they come into our own galaxy as enemy agents controlled by the AI.

Unfortunately I do think there is a balance issue that needs to be addressed with faction 4. You will eventually find certain enemy agents that are typically oblong, travel at high speed, and shoot enormously long particle rays at you at range even from off of the screen! That's faction 4. They almost made me rage quit because they really get too many advantages, but I perservered and went back to the design editor. Their weakness is maneuverability. Their big bad weapon of choice is not turreted so the whole ship has to turn to target you with the death ray. This is not a huge disadvantage because their ships are inordinately fast but if you build a ship that can quickly side step their line of fire and either swarm them or ram them so that they can't turn into you then you can take them down...if you can catch them. Trapping them against asteroids is a typical ploy. Really though, no other faction gives nearly so much trouble...

The only other criticism I have is lag. No it's not really just a hardware issue. I play many other games where it's not an issue. The devs themselves have stated that they've worked really hard on the optimization but the fact is there comes a point where there are so many collisions going on in the galaxy that it can be taxing. I have an i5-4670, 8G ram, nvidia GTX 780 so my hardware is good. But I like faction 2 whose strength is cultivating resources and building up a fleet really quickly. Once I push out a bunch of ships that then create their own AI controlled child ships, the game has alot to track. The devs said to go into options and lower the physics updates per second value so I'll try tweaking that more. But it kind of makes me want to put the game aside now and come back later, maybe playing a different faction and not use a swarming strategy. If you get lag you can also follow a wormhole to a fresh universe, but that too can start to get repetitive.

The fresh content is really about fighting other player designs as enemy agents enter your galaxy. I hope the devs continue to work on the lag issue (maybe instancing parts of the playing field to lower the amount of AI activity needed as the game progresses). I'd also like to see them expand on player interaction by scoring invasions, and maybe add some simple tiered goals with rewards for flipping sections of your galaxy to your faction. I think those things would add alot to the game's longevity for me. Regardless, this is a really creative game. I love looking at it and playing it. It was worth every cent.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042065562', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 7548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2932, 'last_played': 1680550222}
review:
The level of enjoyment you get out of this game will depend on two things, how much you like starships, and your level of creativity.

If you don't like sci-fi and disliked art class when you were young, there is a fair chance you won't get much traction with this game, but if you are creative, imaginative, and love sci-fi, this game is a splendid creativity tool.

It could use some more parts admittedly, some factions have close to 40 while others have only 17 or 16, and it has a few factions that aren't playable at this point, both things I hope will be rectified in the future, but despite a few flaws, this game is undeniably a jewel, a unique and interesting concept.

In the end a Review is about one thing, is the game fun, and for me, and likely for those others who enjoy science-fiction and creativity tools, this game is definitely fun, prepare to sink hours into tweaking the designs for your fighters, capital ships, and stations.

author: {'steamid': '76561198016887117', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 2139, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1870, 'last_played': 1664572770}
review:
“It’s like watching Battlestar Galactica through a kaleidoscope!”

This is one of my favorite 2D games at the moment and WHY I SAY THAT YOU MAY ASK? Let me start with the basics: Reassembly is an action oriented spaceship building game. Created by Anisoptera Games, an independent studio based in Los Angeles. Mainly inspirited in Lego and insect behavior in a world where everything is modular.

Reassembly

You start to build your very own ship piece by piece (ships are assigned a specific value based on their size) and most of the factions will cap out at 8,000P. Obviously it will take some time to get there ;). There are 7 factions in this universe and all of them play and work differently (insectoid, angley, squarish, plantlike or cristal like are some examples). One faction prioritizes high damage while other will get armor mostly. All of them have specific tactics and this will impact in their weapon choices.

You can also unlock most of the factions by killing large and valuable ships aligned to them. Once you destroy an specific amount (or, in other words, you make that faction lose an specific amount of value), you unlock that faction to play with.

Combat

Wield a wide variety of projectile and beam weapons, missiles, rockets and torpedoes, drones, and more against your enemies. Defend yourself with shields, armor, point defense systems, and pure maneuverability. The combat is a mix of skill, tactics, and preparation – an expertly piloted fighter can take down an enemy fleet, but having a well balanced arsenal helps. I can’t explain this better.

Art & environment

Maps are beautiful and the music flows with it. Procedural generated open living worlds where each faction fight for survival and evolution travelling though wormholes. There are usually a lot of “agents” (player fleets) spawning in the universe defending the sectors and spaceships, in Command mode you can pay them to join your fleet and seek you places to emerge. You need to conquer specifics zones to make spaceships emerge or grow your bases. But be careful, the big enemy fleet is looking these places to destroy them. Scavenge for resources, investigate disturbances, self repair, reproduce and take your fleet to the next stage.

 Reassembly Reassembly
 Reassembly Reassembly
 Reassembly 
Artificial Intelligence

AI is incredible. When you have a decent fleet of spaceships including your motherfucking leadership… YOU WILL DIE… A LOT. AI ships can retreat if overwhelmed because they know how to measure the incoming attack. You need to plan how to attack and how to approach the battle and maybe take advantage of impromptu battles between rival factions to recover objectives, or run away after your opponent calls in reinforcements. In screen there can be around 150 ships in crossfire (it will run smoothly and at a decent framerate if you have nice hardware, otherwise you will be laggy).

You can only target 1 enemy at time with you entire fleet and that is a questionable design choice. A small system to target different ships would be nice in Command mode. The overall gameplay is very nice. Sometimes maneuvering big ships can be frustrating in places with a high amount of ships and planets, but is not that bad. We have three control types: Keyboard Only, Mouse and Keyboard, and Gamepad. This is very nice and completely user configurable, from colors to buttons, keys, even control schemes.

And well, we can’t have it all… No true multiplayer mode(can’t fight other players in real-time) the AI takes over other people’s ship designs and places them in your worlds. Obviously, you need to upload your fleet when you go through a wormhole. Last time a tried that Steam completely crashed, so some additional work towards multiplayer would be appreciated. PLEASE LET US PLAY IN REAL-TIME.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044198715', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1425213138}
review:
Poor instruction. Poor UI and poor gameplay.

Every ship drags out and drifts so much that thrusters are really only to propel and fling you in one direction while you wait to crash into something constantly. Simply put, the inertia is very poor.

Haven't played much, and I'll have to play some more to justify blowing 15$ on this mediocre game.

Game feels heavily like an early-access (ie bad) than something that is classified as complete and released.

You bascially throw together some ship with thrusters and weapons on it and fly around and shoot stuff. The end. Every ship looks the same (a chunk of material together with random projectiles coming out of it)

Certainly a regrettable purchase. Legitimate buyer's remorse. Don't let the trolls saying it's good and downvoting anyone saying otherwise tricking you into buying this poorly made and hollow game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985187860', 'num_games_owned': 1345, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 4937, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2361, 'last_played': 1599513755}
review:
Reassembly es un juego de exploración, construcción y batallas espaciales.

Me recordó vagamente a la fase inicial del SPORE, en el estado de célula. Vas recolectando recursos o destruyendo otras facciones para ir evolucionando tu civilización y mejorando tu flota de naves. Al igual que en spore tus diseños además de usarlos tu, también los usa la IA, cosa que me gusta.

La forma de construir es muy intuitiva y fácil para cualquiera, la variedad de las partes y armas es buena y permite mucho juego. El mapa es amplio y la IA enemiga es habilidosa.

La sección de construcción tiene un aliciente, y es un test de tu nave mientras la fabricas en la que son dos IA, una con tu nave y otra con rivales de presupuesto similar luchan al mejor de 3 y así ver donde flojea tu diseño.

Lo mejor de este juego es que tus diseños se comparten como enemigos a otra gente. Existen unos agentes (diseños compartidos por otros jugadores) que suelen ser flotas dificiles que invaden tu galaxia, una delicia.

La cantidad ingente de elementos en movimiento en pantalla sin notar bajar el rendimiento es muy buena, esta muy bien optimizado, al igual que las fisicas, en definitiva es un juego viciante muy recomendable!!

9.1/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197965153857', 'num_games_owned': 829, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 1441, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1441, 'last_played': 1425439536}
review:
A great 2D space game leveraging a simple but versatile geometric ship-building system. You and your fleet blast and farm your way across the expanses, which are densely populated with both dev and player-made hostiles. It's not multiplayer, but the opportunity to share your creations with others, and pit yourself against theirs gives great replayability.
With a bunch of playable 'races', each with their unique build palette, and a spot-on musical accompaniment, this is a game you'll enjoy sinking time into... A lot of time.[7.0]

author: {'steamid': '76561197998629627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 1096, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1096, 'last_played': 1427010253}
review:
Bought the game yesterday. 18 hours later I can say I've gotten my money's worth. Reassembly is compelling and addictive as you try and work out how systems function and such. The combat feels good although sometimes I get caught on an object and destroyed for my weakness which is lame but doeasn't feel cheap. The ship editor is fantastic and works very well and mostly does what I'm trying to do. I have only encountered a couple of minor bugs so far. Overall I would recommend and heartily encourage everyone to try this game. The ship editor and AI arena are by themselves worth the $15. 

9/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198214703568', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 10474, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 596, 'last_played': 1523770472}
review:
What else should I say about this game?
Basically it's a 2D space game where you have to make money by kiling other space ships, simple huh? Not really, because you get to make your OWN spaceship using different blocks. And because you do, so do other people, and their ships shown up in your game and destroy you. Boom. Unless of course, your spaceship is good enough to make theirs go boom.

Pros

Build you own spaceship
Blocks of stuff running around, how can that not be good
Beautiful textures
Fight the ships other people build
You get to waste too much time

Cons

Nothing, ok but the dev needs to add bigger maps and multiplayer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072402725', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 18775, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4083, 'last_played': 1700122287}
review:
First part is only for in-depth explanation, also may contain SPOILERS:

Scroll past for basics

[spoiler]I have been playing this game a lot recently, and I love it.  I'm usually a little worried when I look at an alpha stage game because I have a few that I have bought in the past and never play, not because it was necessarily a bad game, or that the devs were bad, but because I have a very short attention span, and a lot of games.  The games that I tend to focus on are ones like reassembly, because you can take it as seriously as you want and the gameplay is ongoing, as in, you can go through wormholes and either upload the fleet you have currently in your saved ship designs chart, or you can actually 'go through' the wormhole and end up in an entirely different universe.  This is actually the part that I like most about the game, the first time I ran into a wormhole I decided to see what it did, after I went through my computer crashed and it deleted my whole save, which made me kinda sad, mainly because I thought my fleet just leaft me wouldn't come back, but ever since it has worked great.

Other than it crashing that one time, this game is spectacular, you are provided with 8 factions to play as(I think there are 8 playable one's anyway), and each faction has loads of powerful weapons and methods of defense.  The game makes it feel as though you are actually the commander of a whole race(being able to change the production of any factory weilding ship or station), and a power limit that allows you to construct massive ships bristling with weaponry.  The graphics are 2D, but that seriously doesn't matter, the visual effects are stunning, and the sound effects are also top-notch.  The ship crafting system is just like they promise, you can build anything you want, given you have ingenuity and know how shapes work.  The soundtrack is surprisingly good for galactic domination, and has a very spacy, electronicy feel.  The A.I. is pretty smart, not human smart, but it will use it's advantages against you, especially agent ships, cuz remember, they could be made by me, or you, or anybody.  With all that other stuff in mind, I have a pretty nice computer and a really old and outdated monitor, so i run most games on ultra, except crysis, or that type of stuff.  Most of the time this game runs fine, but if i have a big fleet, and im fighting a huge battle with hundreds of ships, it gets quite laggy until everything is dead.[/spoiler]

The basic facts are as follows:
Pros:
- Gameplay is fast paced and fun
- Makes you feel like the king of a space empire
- Ship-building system is perfect
- Graphics yo
- Sounds great
- [spoiler]Agents add tremendous difficulty[/spoiler]
- it's quality shit, buy it

Cons:
- Large fleet battles can cause lag
- crashes are few and far between, but excpected, cuz beta

author: {'steamid': '76561197993082660', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 465, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 245, 'last_played': 1511289534}
review:
Really funny game, unluky there is no increase in difficulty level and no real multiplayer, so it gets a bit repetitive over time.

The concept itself is so beautiful that the game really deserves to be bought.

The only pity thing is that it is soo close to become a must, few changes, don't know if the author will implement this few changes.... then the game would be worth much more then the actual price.
Would be great to see more parts introduced to build ships, a really aggressive A.I. that actually kills your small fleet... but no... u re safe and able to explore really similar universes. Nice the idea to introduce agents (fleets from real umans A.I. controlled).

The in game musik is amazing too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198059880635', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 21938, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 5808, 'last_played': 1563325228}
review: This is the game I have been waiting for to play for years, If you enjoy open ended design this puts other games like MOO or SPORE to shame, you have true freedom to build great ships of all different shapes and sizes and then to fight them. The biggest things missing are pvp and perhaps a large strategy multi sector type of modes but as of right now in its current state the game feels very polished and will waste hundreds of my hours :) I would reccomend this game to anyone who loved playing with legos, and likes to create things then blow them up!! I would just wish for more races and some sort of pvp.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053778973', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 6344, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4356, 'last_played': 1602080098}
review:
Love this game, all of the people here can simply explain how great this game is but a few things I must point out just to help you:
-Don't go into the wormhole until you are powerful enough; the first world is designed to have agents (player made fleets) to be weak power levels, stronger than you from the start but still relatively weak in general. The moment you leave to the next world, you'll be fighting random power varieties of fleets so be warned
-Objectives don't need to be done right away, take your time, agents don't need to die immediately and if you lose, go somewhere else, gather and build and become stronger
-To make REALLY GOOD SHIPS requires a lot of time building, to where I spend 50% of the time building and fine tuning and 50% of the time playing. Not all good ships are required to be blocky and ugly.
