author: {'steamid': '76561198026081304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1028, 'last_played': 1642658590}
review:
Great game, if you like building and improving spaceships and and simple gameplay, don't hesitate and get this game. There's enough variation in the spaceship building blocks and enemies to make you think. You've got to experiment with the various builds and styles of play to get a winning combination. Also, you can design and add ships to your own fleet, adding more strategic combinations of missiles, rays and drones. Great fun and will eat hours of your life. 
Highly recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044758616', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 2555, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2515, 'last_played': 1434604237}
review:
This game has been a pleasent surprise. Noticed only a couple small bugs so far. Half the time I'm just plotting my next ship or a counter to something that tore my last idea in half. Needs more factions and less skating on ice feeling when flying. Otherwise definately worth it.  

Pros:
~ Easy to learn controls and UI
~ Game mechanics/speed is more or less controlled by the player
~ Different factions with different building materials offer a different feel.
~ Custom colors, I hate when you have to look a certain way.
~ So many different ways to build your fleet! I felt like a kid again watching my legos come alive haha.

Things I wanted to mention that aren't so positive:
~ Ive noticed some of the stations don't build themselves after capturing the node. They sit idle until I edit them, after I edit they will grow and start to function.
~ I mentioned the feeling of skating on ice. even with well placed thrusters its still hard to control your ship.
~ In ine point of the tutorial the game asks you to build a ship with a ship with a factory and then have that ship produce another to complete the cycle to grow your fleet. I love this idea but after you've made the first one spawn they dont really expand they all kinda stay in the same spot :*( I gave them thrusters to move! go kill stuff! Anyways.

8/10 Great fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043221198', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 6649, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1743, 'last_played': 1601592772}
review: I do like the game but the in game different factions are radically unblanced and the ultimate ship is essentially a cube or rectangle with a bunch of weapons and engines.  There are some creative powerful ships out there but they are few and far between.  In specific i am almost constantly up against an agent called the lasercube, and its fucking boring as hell because i essentially have to break out a long range super fast sniping ship and kite it to death or make a clone of it, produce several of them and just out laser cube the laser cube.  This is also annoying.  Of course some faction arent even able to snipe things.  The faction that is orange red yellow has such weak hulls that the laser cube destroys them on sight, and with no long range weapons, and no shields the ROY (red yellow orange) faction is weak as balls against the others.  Its really annoying when my fleet of 7 or more 4000 cost ROY ships just get blown to shit by an agent looking at them the wrong way.  In short its a cool game, i do enjoy it, it just frustrates the crap out of me because the factions are unblanced as fuck, all the agents i see are basically cubes or rectangles, and I purchased the game right before the price dropped to $15.  As it stands if the price drops again, or if the game is somehow rebalanced to make cubes and rectangles not the most effcient ship design, or to somehow award ships with greater aestetic appeal more functionality, or really just something to balance all the factions and make them all equally capable of fighting with eachother, then I can recomend the game.  As it stands I would say buy it if you enjoy playing with legos a lot, and if legos weren't one of your favorite toys then this isn't for you as of right now.  I also noticed a lot of reviews talking about crashing and deleting save files but i never had those problems.  Not sure why, but those need to be fixed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197964234833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 5713, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2172, 'last_played': 1510802661}
review:
Get this game!  It is nearly perfect!  If you are wondering "Will I like this game?"  The answer is yes!  Ship design and building is flawless.  Handling and combat are satisfying and responsive to what you design and the changes you make.  If you like Lego (building blocks not games) or buildy games like Terraria, Minecraft, Gratuitous Space Battles you will loves this.

Endless replayability, like a bucket full of Lego bricks.  The last two games that made me feel this way were FTL and Terraria.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014358372', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 1801, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1163, 'last_played': 1667145805}
review:
Gra dużo leprza niż się wydaje na pierwszy żut oka. Najprościej określił bym Reassembly jako połączenie Space Rangers 2 i Floow. Żyjący orginicznie rozwijający się wszechświat i nasza w nim rola ani nie za mała ani nie za duża, za to taka, gdzie z czasem wpływamy na walki terytorialne dużych frakcji i po prostu mamy mase zabawy z rozwoju.
Zdecydowanie polecam. A tu macie video z moimi pierwszymi wrażeniami z gry: http://youtu.be/sKpzGqDe73c

author: {'steamid': '76561198071520533', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 6718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2503, 'last_played': 1611683218}
review:
Узнал об этой игре случайно, осматривая раздел стратегий в Steam. Посмотрел пару обзоров на ютубе, решил купить её и не пожалел об этом. Начинаешь на хиленьком истребителе, который разносят все подряд. Но постепенно собирая ресурсы,     развивая свой корабль, а развивать его можно сколь угодно долго, так как ограничений как таковых нет вообще. Можно построить что угодно и каких угодно размеров. Это очень и очень круто. И вот постепенно развиваешься, ставишь несколько фабрик, либо нанимаешь союзные войска и спустя какое-то время суровый прокачанный корабль во главе космической флотилии идёт победоносной поступью по вражеским секторам, уничтожая всё на своём пути и захватывая новые земли. И вот я сделал хороший корабль, открыл все 7 фракций и возникает вопрос - и это всё? О нет! Оказалось, что у каждой фракции своя ветка технологий и за каждую фракцию стиль и тактика игры разительно отличаются.
  В целом если по пунктам:
+ Весьма большой случайно генерируемый мир
+ Отсутствие ограничений при строительстве корабля
+ Разнообразные не похожие друг на друга фракции
+ Приятная графика
+ Живой мир, в нём постоянно что-то происходит. 
+ Красивые спецэффекты. Как разваливаются подбитые корабли, мне наверное не надоест смотреть никогда.
+ Полностью разрушаемый мир

- У некоторых фракций слишком мало технологий
- В мире всё же мало разнообразия
- У двух фракций есть солнечные батареии, которые ведут себя читерно
- Нет хотя бы небольшого описания фракций при их выборе
- Отсутствие каких-либо настрек мира при начале игры

  А ещё не помешали бы моды и воркшоп. С модами эта игра была бы воистинну превосходна!

author: {'steamid': '76561198007644974', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 40, 'playtime_forever': 710, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 670, 'last_played': 1433466053}
review:
Fantastic little game, but of course it has its flaws too.

First off, basically everything about this game is something to love, the graphics are really simple but work so damn well, the framerate NEVER drops below 60, the sound and music are also simplistic but lovely and the gameplay is some really incredibly fun stuff!

At the start, the game throws a ton of mechanics at you. Once you either get a friend to explain it to you or re-read all texts a few times, you'll get what the different terms mean, get used to them and be able to work with them.

While I imagined the gameplay to get repetitive at some time, it actually stayed incredibly fresh and fun for all this time. You keep getting new ideas on what to do, new things to try out, you can keep expanding and if all's boring, just start a new game in a different faction, changing up the gameplay a TON.

The other thing is: you NEED a good upload speed to play this game, because once you close it, it has to sync about 20MB of data (the world and ships) to the Steam Cloud, stopping you from playing other games during that time, and is just plain annoying. The even worse bit is that DISABLING Steam Cloud syncing seems to erase all ships you've created (it at least happened for me, not sure if that's exactly the cause), so you gotta deal with it somehow...

EITHER WAY, this game is so damn awesome, please go play it, I'll tell ya, once you get used to the mechanics, it'll be an enormous time sink!

author: {'steamid': '76561198005949347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 2428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2086, 'last_played': 1426030475}
review:
This game is beautiful. A physics-based WASD space shooter nestled in the most enjoyable sandbox builder I've ever played.

[h1] Pros [/h1]
[list]
  [*] Your ship is constantly rebuilding itself - leading to great gameplay moments like sniping enemy cores, narrow escapes, on-the-fly hull redesign, etc...
  [*] Instead of being a solo ship, you are part of a faction. You gain acess to new tech and bigger ships by advancing your faction's power which does a great job of making you feel integrated into the game world.
  [*] Each faction is very diverse, with its own unique attributes and building elements. These constraints help shipbuilding to stay fresh and encourage experimentation.
  [*] Fantastic ship editor makes it fun and easy to make your designs real.
  [*] Good tutorial to get you started with the core mechanics.
  [*] Community content - at any time you can approach a wormhole and upload your fleet. These fleets can then spawn in other players' games. What makes this awesome is that you don't just encounter single ships from these fleets, but whole communities with multiple ship styles from the same user.
  [*] A sense of progression. I typically lose interest in sandbox builders where you have to collect resources to use in crafting. Reassembly uses point-based ship construction, so you don't have to collect resources to build your ship - just to expand your point cap. This gives you concrete goals to work towards over time, while again providing constraints to motivate continual re-design of your fleet.
[/list]

[h1] Cons [/h1]
[list]
  [*] You haven't purchased this game yet! Go support these developers!
[/list]

author: {'steamid': '76561198030954535', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 1625, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 855, 'last_played': 1488898814}
review:
Nach ca 10 Std. Spielzeit ist es Zeit dieses Juwel zu bewerten. Anfänglich war ich doch etwas skeptisch, da ich nicht sicher war, ob mich das Spielprinzip fesseln kann. Aber es kann. Und zwar in einem nicht vorhersehbaren Ausmaß :D

Die Grafik ist stimmig und das Entwerfen von immer neuen Schiffen macht unglaublich viel Spaß. Ich ertappte mich dabei 5 Std am Stück zu spielen, ohne an die Zeit zu denken. Und das will was heißen.

Es läuft stabil und die immer neu generierten Welten haben einen hohen Wiederspielwert. 

Das Prinzip ist eindeutig Mikrobiologischem Leben entnommen und zeigt wie einfach im Grunde Leben und Evolution ist.
Man kann sogar behaupten, dass es im Grunde eine philosophische Frage aufwirft, nämlich...wer desingt eigentlich neue Raumschiffe...ähhhh...Lebensformen. ;)

Aber um hier nicht völlig den Faden zu verlieren beschränke ich mich darauf eine Kaufempfehlung auszusprechen.

Auch von mir gibts ein kurzes Let's Play, um die Grundprinzipien verständlich zu machen. Vielen Dank an die Entwickler, die wirklich etwas, für mich, einzigartiges geschaffen haben.

http://youtu.be/B9x2vlflexA

author: {'steamid': '76561197966610754', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 1039, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1008, 'last_played': 1567732838}
review:
tl;dr Spore meets SubSpace (aka Continuum), 8/10. Remember SubSpace? Need I say more? I do? Okay.

As others have said, this game is extremely addictive. In a good way. The ship editor in itself is hours of lego-style building fun, but add to that a really immersive single-player world with player-made ships and you have a game that is both simple and compelling at the same time. 

Definitely worth the money, tons of replayability. Summarizing my experience as follows:

Pros:
- Great physics / destructable levels, and combat is super fun.
- Awesome soundtrack.
- World is huge but not infinite. That's a good thing for a space game.
- Building ships is surprisingly fun. I'm not usually the type to want to buy a game then spend hours in an editor customizing things. The editor is very featureful and forgiving (undo, redo, copy paste), unlike many other in-game editors out there.
- Sending your ship into a wormhole uploads your fleet into the ether so they can be run in other player games as the bad guys, Spore-style! In other words, tons of player-made content.
- If you get sick of your world, fly into a wormhole and explore a parallel dimension instead.

Cons:
- Controls are a little quirky, especially on gamepads. Don't use a gamepad. Occasionally you'll find yourself slamming into an asteroid and getting completely stuck because the "fly backwards" key gets completely rotated and you and up flying into the asteroid and flailing around until you're killed by a passing enemy.
- Ship editor is missing a MANUAL test flight option to get a sense of the maneuverability of the ship you spent an hour making. 
- Ship editor is missing important info about total mass / total thrust / total energy created which could help to approximate the above stuff. Only total resource capacity is listed-- everything else you have to calculate yourself.
- NO MULTIPLAYER! The player-made content is fun in SP, but a game like this just begs for multiplayer.
- Once you've maxed out points, Actual gameplay is 1-dimensional. Mostly consists of flying around and shooting everything you see-- or if you're like me and setup auto-fire, it's just flying around and letting the ship shoot everything for you. You can explore to find new bases, but that doesn't really give you anything.

On the last two points, I wonder if I'm just misunderstanding some of the game dynamics, but it seems like unlocking bases is just there to occupy your time. I also don't really know if you can ever wipe out another faction. It would be great if:

- You could watch bases expand over time, including size and number of ships, so you actually have more allies flying around. Ditto for enemies that go unchecked.
- You could actually attack enemy bases and eventually wipe out factions. It would be awesome if each faction actually had a stronghold base you have to kill in order to wipe out an enemy.
- There were new factions added over time, including to existing regions. Maybe I haven't played for long enough, but it seems like the same factions just exist in perpetuity.

There it is. Lots of cons because the pros seem obvious to me. It's damn fun! It could be even better if the above things were addressed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984877534', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 5467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3135, 'last_played': 1688516312}
review:
This game is awesome.  Ever played a game and wished you could tweak your ship?  Well now you can.
Any type of ship imaginable is buildable: Carriers that launch leigons of drone fighters; Battleships with heavy cannons and a myriad of point defense lasers; Missile Cruisers with racks upon racks of guided missiles; Destroyers with cannons, lasers, beam weapons, and torpedo launchers; Fighters with rapid-fire plasma guns, lasers, and rockets.  Weapons can be bound to control groups and can be set to fire in grouped bursts or in a continuous chain.

The game starts you out with a well-made tutorial.  It provides guidance on learning the game and getting your fleet up and running (yes, you can build ships that can build more ships), without being intrusive or pushy.  All of this building requires competing for and collecting the resources that grow on nearby asteroids.  These raw resources can then be used to construct additional ships or exchanged at one of the friendly stations you've activated for credits to fund research and fleet upgrades.

The physics in this game are fantastic.  Fire a heavy cannon, and your ship recoils.  Hit something or blow something up, and chunks fly off and blow apart.  The field of wreckage that remains after an epic battle is part of what makes this game so satisfying.

The graphics are beautiful.  Colors and effects are vibrant. (Just go look at the screenshots!)

The music is suitable and soothing, but not particularly noteworthy, but the sound effects from firing weapons are right on point.

There are still a few bugs.  The game never seems to remember my control settings, and the game sometimes has trouble starting (restarting the launcher seems to work for the latter).

TLDR:  I don't usually write reviews, but this game is too awesome not to.  It is a definite must buy and well worth the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002939840', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 2193, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1323, 'last_played': 1644860811}
review:
Co bych tomu měl psát je to supr uber hra, pokud milujete " strategi a vlastní tvorba (editor build 2D) staveb " tak není co řešit.

Hra je nenáročná a zaujme i po několika hodin protože mužete stavět do haleluja omezuje vás snad jen vaše předsavivost.

Vše je udělané do vesmírních lodí.

Časem hraní kde už si dokážete postavit nějakému silnějšímu týpkoj " AGENT " tak se vám odemikají frakce či struktury lodí na které se dostane te při výběru nové hry,

POZOR NENÍ REKLAMA, pokud znáte hru BattleShips Forever tak zde je jakoby pokračování ( prostě oujeea ).

Přeji příjemnou zábavu :).

author: {'steamid': '76561198051816523', 'num_games_owned': 238, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 2083, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1928, 'last_played': 1676520160}
review:
Wow, Is all I can say really.
This is just an incredible game, I bought it and started playing at around 8PM, Next thing you know, I take a second glance at the clock and it's 5AM.

There are 7 factions, they all play and work differently, One faction is the high damage, high armour faction, but all but one of their weapons cannot do damage to shields. Another faction has incredibly low armour/health, but has the highest damaging weapons. You unlock the other factions by killing large valuable ships of that faction, once you kill a certain amount, or a certain value of ship, You unlock that faction to play as.

Ships are assigned value based on their size, So for instance, if your build cap is 500P, and you build a ship up to say, 460P, your ship is worth 460P. Most factions will cap out at 8,000P, and it will take some time to get there.

Inside each map, There are usually around 8-10 "Agents" Agents being player fleets spawning in your world, They can range from being total garbage, to an impossible force. Each time you go through a Wormhole, the way you change maps, It will spawn your current fleet setup randomly in other players worlds. 

The gameplay is very nice, It plays like a twin stick shooter and it works. The game itself is very well optimized, even after spawning around 150 large ships it still ran smoothly and at a decent framerate. The graphics are nice and stylized.

I really have nothing negative to say about this game, It's just amazing.

With 22 hours in the game, I've managed to completely clear only 2 of the 7 Factions, By that I mean, unlocking all the parts, upgrading the build cap to max and building a very powerful ship. With it's recent price drop to 17$, It's DEFINITELY worth the price, You'll be getting a lot of game.

Solid 10/10, You NEED to buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198060663769', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1659, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1065, 'last_played': 1688676107}
review: It took me about an hour to fall into this game but once I finally got the hang of it I was hooked.  Its not until you can start producing your own personal fleet of ships that this game really starts to shine.  The graphics are beautiful, however there are some slowdowns when the huge battles start.  I turned a few physics options down a bit and it was much better.  I felt like I took a bit of a chance buying this in early access but I feel like its well worth it.  I hope to see some more multiplayer options soon.  There is a lot to do already to keep you busy while the devs work on even more content as it sets now.

author: {'steamid': '76561198108269527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 401, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1429064408}
review:
Reassembly is a game that is difficult to categorize. There are elements of building, space combat, and rts (in a somewhat abstract way). The game allows great creativity in shipbuilding style and combat philosphy. 

I find this game to be great fun. You can start with a pre-built ship, or make your own right away. The game includes an AI driven tester that will pit your design against other designs so that you can tweak and perfect your ship before flying it. I prefer to fly around and earn some credits first for upgrades. The goal is simple - expand your territory, earn credits, use credits to upgrade the power level of ship you are permitted to fly, unlock upgrades and build better ships.

The game learns from how you play and from facing your ships. Eventually you will face ships made by other players. Also you will unlock other factions that you can play which have different ship components. The replay value is immense as no playthrough will ever be identical to another. 

The graphics are clean and simple, not ultra-detailed, with nice effects, slightly retro and modern at the same time.  The game includes excellent controller support for in-game play, but for ship creation you have to use mouse and keyboard. I think controller support for the building phase of the game would probably be awkward and difficult to implement, so I don't blame the devs...

10/10 If there is something wrong with this game, I don't know what it is!

author: {'steamid': '76561197973546137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 777, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 680, 'last_played': 1541833940}
review:
Like building ships? Buy this game. Like hectic combat? Buy this game. Like leading fleets with very little control over your subordinates? Buy this game. Like minimalistic art style that still manages to be beautiful, where you can sit and watch the asteroid flowers grow for hours on end in a strange zen-like state? Buy this game.

(I kickstarted this game, and am by far the most pleased with this product out of any other game I've "invested" in)

author: {'steamid': '76561198025216321', 'num_games_owned': 555, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1108, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1035, 'last_played': 1484525117}
review:
I am REALLY amazed about this game. This game absolutely nails the playability and usability. For me this game is up there with FTL and Minecraft, where you can just keep playing and playing for the fun of the experience itself, not the winning.

The building of new spacehips, trying out combinations, and just trying to make things look good is a lot of fun. Combined with the amazing slickness of the editor you can spend hours in a Zen-like mode of tweaking, playing, and tweaking some more.

What sets this game apart as well is that you fight the creations of other players, and that others will play against yours. That makes you care about your creations much more than you would have in a purely single player game.

All in all highly recommended if you like 2D space shooters and building games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984487409', 'num_games_owned': 369, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 2407, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1990, 'last_played': 1424991474}
review:
This is a giant sandbox top down builder/shooter. You design your ships and stations then head out to conquer the galaxy. I'm not sure how each race works, two of them seem useless, and another two seem endgame only.. Maybe I'm missing something when trying to figure out what they are for.

If you love topdown sandbox shooters where you build your fleet and have amazing lightshows... I mean lazer fights! Then grab the game, I've got my money's worth already and am still enjoying it.

Build ships that look like things (beatles, scorpions, star destroyer, etc. Blow stuff up and enjoy the lightshow, at this price how can you say no?!

author: {'steamid': '76561197997316475', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 657, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 528, 'last_played': 1482609073}
review: Somewhere between the arcade classic Asteroids and the joy of playing with LEGOs is Reassembly.  The learning curve can be steep, the balance a bit off, but the gameplay remains addictive and designing your own spaceships is a breeze.  I designed an Imperial Star Destroyer that craps out Millennium Falcons and Enterprises.  'Nuff said.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024966235', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1963, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 862, 'last_played': 1585002224}
review: A well-designed space exploration game.  While gameplay has the potential to get somewhat repetetive after a time, the ship-building modes allow for endless experimentation.  The ship builder was surprisingly well-designed, and controls were easy and intuitive.  My only complaint is that, when storing games on the Steam Cloud, data compaction and sync times are extremely long.  This doesn't affect gameplay, though.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044812702', 'num_games_owned': 255, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 1440, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1059, 'last_played': 1465200608}

author: {'steamid': '76561198124328535', 'num_games_owned': 362, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 9388, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1415, 'last_played': 1592623387}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040885905', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 4841, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3750, 'last_played': 1681091150}
review:
Seriously an amazing game if you're looking for something to stretch your creative muscles.  You choose one of many playable factions, each unique in the parts and weapons available to them.  Using said parts, you create a 2D spaceship and begin to pioneer your faction to victory.

Things to note:
-This game has no story.  It is purely driven by you making a story yourself, or simply wanting to conquer the generated world.

-All movement in the game is physics based, and your ships are only as good as you build them.  This means there is something similar to a puzzle/strategy aspect of the game when building your ships.  If this is unappealing, I would be hesitant to recommend this game to you.
    A possible solution to this problem is the implementation of the Steam Workshop.  This allows people to upload entire factions/fleets for you to use, but in my opinion you are mission out on half if not more of the game if you aren't building things.

-Replay value is arguable, and very dependant on the player.  If you are someone who likes experimenting with strategies, or challenging yourself by say, limiting your options by a personal rule, then you will most likely find it easy to sink hours into Reassembly.

    In closing, I will simply say that Reassembly is a very rewarding game for those who enjoy top-down shooters, side scrollers, and creating functional and even beautiful things.  If you find it difficult to find personal motivation with a game, maybe double check other games on your wishlist before buying.

P.S. If you're into systematically destroying A.I. populations, this game could be for you.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970818992', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 1856, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1668, 'last_played': 1425523959}

author: {'steamid': '76561198003552620', 'num_games_owned': 461, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 596, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 474, 'last_played': 1450999723}
review:
After kickstarting this with high hopes, the end result is pretty disappointing.  

Building ships isn't very fun in their editor.  There is an inverse relationship between how good a ship is in a fight, versus how cool it looks and how fun it is to actually fly around in.  The world rapidly fills up with similar, boring, min-max ships designed by other players, which you need your own min-maxed boring, un-fun ships to fight against successfully.  The alternative path to victory is basically, get bigger numbers and spam more boring ships in a bigger blob of boring than the other guy.  

There just isn't much of a designed "game" in here.  The tricky part where you make doing the individual actions you perform in the game cohere into something interesting, balance out various weapons and tactics, etc, seems not to have been done at all as yet.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044831489', 'num_games_owned': 534, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 173, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1672084317}
review:
Kickstarted this game because it looked awesome.

Essentially, procedurally-generated (and with wormholes, basically infinite) shmup with a focus on customizing your ship. It gives you basically lego-style building blocks (e.g. square or triangular hull blocks) plus various components like your ship's core, harvesters, storage, etc. as well as a plethora of increasingly fun weapons to use. Once you have your ship, you simply fly out and battle all the ships in the world -- this isn't procedurally generated, but the devs made a huge number of ships, and it'll take ships other players made and put them in your world, so there's a lot to blow up.

Overall, and excellent and really replayable game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198150496857', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3481, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1236, 'last_played': 1485778175}

author: {'steamid': '76561198075738086', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 1809, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1720, 'last_played': 1538968219}
review:
Bought this game for 31.99$, a day later it's 16.99$. Not even mad, played it for 11 hours straight. 11/10 would pay double price again. As a fan of stardrive this game takes the spaceship building aspect far and above it, floating aimlessly in space looking for ships to destroy and factions to unlock, then all of a sudden a super mega ultra death juggernaut destroys my fleet in one hit... Next objective? REVENGE. 10 hours later, mission success.

It's a hard game to describe with words, either watch some videos/streams, or take a chance and buy it! the price is a steal!

author: {'steamid': '76561197962754388', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 6908, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 482, 'last_played': 1586814695}

author: {'steamid': '76561198008241330', 'num_games_owned': 619, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 919, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 796, 'last_played': 1478829156}
review:
Game is great. Though a little scarce on parts at the moment, I hope they are planning on adding more parts and weapons. You can make just about anything in this game from tiny scout fighters to giant dreadnaughts and space stations. Installed it and played it trying to keep making the better ship only to lose track of time 4 hours later. This is a great time killer. Graphics are unique, gameplay is solid, though can be repetitive at times with gathering resources.

I do hope they plan on adding ship sharing perhaps via steam workshop. Currently the only wait to see other peoples ships are to hunt down “agents” which are usually player made ships most of the time. I’m still grasping the game within the first 4 hours if me losing track of time.  Hopefully in the future, we have the ability of a more diverse fleet command system, and more parts. All in all, great game for $15 full price. 

EDIT: I should note that after putting more time into the game, I have found that you can download player fleets by just going to the Reassembly Homepage and looking at the sync list. Its as easy as just downloading and importing fleets. Check it out: http://www.anisopteragames.com/sync/latest.html

On another note, I only played as the first faction. Upon unlocking more factions, you have unique parts and weapons used by that faction. So there is quite a variety with the 6 or 7 different factions available right now. Definitely hard to break away from this, as I'm constantly facing player made fleets and always trying to enhance my fleet to defeat that fleet. I was constantly defeated by one fleet for about an hour before finally upgrading and fine tuning my weapons to defeat them. Simply one of the best arcade style games I've played in a long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198088783978', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1424414023}
review:
Now lets not get confused here. THIS IS A GOOD GAME. It is fun, its scope is huge, and its use of simple game machanics to create a vast, exciting, interesting game rivals that of minecraft. The reason I can't recomend this is just . . . it's TOO addicting. Some might think of that as a great thing and I'm sure the maker is thrilled, though for those who already spend too much time with games and aren't looking to lose hours of time infront of your screen may want to stay away.

tldr; good game, time eater

author: {'steamid': '76561198160813700', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 2617, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1352, 'last_played': 1597367597}

author: {'steamid': '76561198090868483', 'num_games_owned': 330, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 26571, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1598, 'last_played': 1710030805}
review:
Let me just begin by saying this game is in early developement and it may have its bugs but still is worth playing through. the gameplay and concept are a jewel among other games. there are strategy and shooter elements along with casual elements that make this game just an all around excellent experience both for hardcore action players and more relaxed casual players. 
The ability to make your own ship one block at a time and perfect it and then see other stations and ships spawn your design is a beautiful site. This is an excellent marriage of strategy and shooter along with a wonderful atmospheric environment. the price for this game may seem a little high but I personally think it is well worth the price for the experience you can have in the game.

pros
- modular ship building
- living ever changing environment
- unique playable factions each specializing in a particular playstyle.
- interesting encounters with other players ship designs.
- early access
- inifinite ways to play
cons
- early access
- lack of uniqueness with some factions
- weak factions
- lacking content

author: {'steamid': '76561197970635085', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 1788, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1782, 'last_played': 1515578944}

author: {'steamid': '76561198141129230', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 3001, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2338, 'last_played': 1458795846}
review:
When I first saw this game I was overjoyed. I bought it, even though $30 is quite a steep price for a game of this size, but for the most part it was worth it. Ever since I bought it the Dev has been active in updating the game and has made some major improvements on the ai and visuals as a whole. I think one of the latest updates that gave the ships and stations a glow based on their color added even more to the game's beauty. I love the idea of being able to design my own ships and take over the galaxy. Not to mention getting to see other people's creations (and getting to blow them to ****ing pieces). 

But this game does start to get old after a certain point. At the moment there are 7 factions, and I've been able to get to the endgame of just about each one of them, but after you do that.... there's nothing really to do. You conquer one galaxy, move on to the next, and do the same exact thing, and the hardest ships sadly are always the same, (the blue and pinkish purple ones) which are located in the middle, which sadly never changes. Faction balancing is also a problem right now. The red faction atm is completly useless and almost impossible to get anywhere. The blocks it has are far weaker than any other faction (other than its weapons, which do pack a punch) and its ships get completely destroyed almost instantly when you're in the starting stage with the faction. Even when you start creating bigger ships with them they get crushed by other factions who have far better blocks. That brings me to my next point, the lack of options when it comes to blocks for some factions. For example, a faction like the green race (the 2nd option in the menu) has 47 different blocks, whereas some of the others will only have a little over 20 (and are very limited when it comes to weapon variance). 

Another thing that should have been in this game but is not is multiplayer. Sure there's going to be tournaments where you can pit your ships against other ships, but only with the ai using your ship instead of you... If I created a ship to my liking, I want to use that ship to my liking in a pvp environment. Sadly the Dev said that this is probably not going to happen beacuse he'd have to take the game apart to implement a multiplayer function. So if you're going into this game thinking that that's going to be an option. It's most likely not going to happen.

Overall, this game is very fun and I would definatley reccomend buying it, but wait until after it comes out this coming thursday (the 19th) because it's going to be going down to $15 I believe. The creativity in this game is nearly endless, and many good times can be had, but unfortunetly you won't beable to do this with friends in the same galaxy and once you do conquer that galaxy, it's going to get repetetive.

I'd give it an 8/10. Pick it up and enjoy it if you want a creative experience in the sci-fi world.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049688895', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 5031, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1933, 'last_played': 1670132387}
review:
I was beyond skeptical about this game.
But I figured... hey, I love ship building games, I love re-thinking my strategy, I like unique weird little games without 3d grahpics.

So I played it for a bit. It was fun. I don't know where the tipping point was... I think it was at 3am. I realized I was hooked. I was rebuilding my ship yet again and out of nowhere the background music changes. 
OH MY GOD THE MUSIC.

This game smashed my expectations for uniqueness and the music... that just made my day / night / whatever time doesn't matter anymore.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079538935', 'num_games_owned': 194, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 3719, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1205, 'last_played': 1671610251}
review: Flew around for a bit, dying a lot and making a small living out of hit and run tactics, reactivated a station, got 500C, though I was rich, bought lots of upgrades, made a missle ship, went into enemie teritory and reactivated a station. Mass war ensued for the next half hour, many big ships destroyed, many upgrades were bought. Killed more stuff blah blah blah awhile later I was making my own ships and spawning them around me, lost a battle with my carrier and 61 ships vs. 3 battle ships(last one got a lucky hit on me). Respawned then started making ships that make more ships, started selling them for money. Am now rich 11/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198044571833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 5269, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4330, 'last_played': 1448695890}
review:
Great Game 9.7/10. Build ship fleet and destroy other ships is great

Short Review:

+ Beautiful graphics
+ Good gameplay
+ Awesome features
+ Randomly Generated World
+ Wormhole feature to make a new world for replayability
+Amazing ship building feature

-Saves can be deleted from bugs that I've encountered (3 TIMES ALREADY)
-Performance issues on Yellow Plant Faction, even with beefy PC's

Long Version: Reassembly is a vector-graphics game with a great original topic. This game can be very addicting. The one thing i do encounter in this game is the repititive gameplay. Eventually, you will get maximum Power to upgrade your ship until you cant upgrade it anymore, creating a big, strong ship/fleet. When you go to this part, you will see it is easy to pick off the small and huge ships in the center, even if they swarm you, you would just easily kill all of them off. I do recommend to the Dev(s) to create bigger ships or even create it so that the bigger P you have, the bigger the enemy ships get. Sort of like "evolution" (idk lol). This suggestion would take time, but will be worth it.

     I have played this game for hours and it is extremely fun to play. I get more excited for updates in the game rather than updates for others (except Running With RIfles), even if they are just bugfixes. 

Overall: Game is very fun and addictive. its gr8 m8 i r8 8/8

author: {'steamid': '76561197970917644', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 3276, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1437, 'last_played': 1638920045}
review:
This is a bit like SPaZ with total ship customization. Completing objectives like capturing points and killing enemies awards you with upgrade points that you can use to buy more weapons and systems for your ships. You can start from the ground up to customize your ship, which gives you the freedom to make a spectacularly crappy ship or the ship of awesome, all governed by how many upgrade points you put into ship total size. It's so fun, and I constantly go back and tweak ships when I unlock new techs. 

The price is higher than an indie game, and that's a bit of a negative, but there is plenty of value in the ship customization. There are different ship races to unlock, so there is a bit of replay value. The ship races differ dramatically, so it feels different evey time you start fresh with a new race.

Creativity in ship building is the shining point of this game, and I'm glad I bought it.

This game is fun and functional in its early access state, so don't worry about buying something buggy and unfinished. It's good!

author: {'steamid': '76561198124636722', 'num_games_owned': 208, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 10945, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4219, 'last_played': 1575179933}
review:
I've never posted a review on Steam before, but Reassembly compelled me to do so.

Summary: This game is still in beta. It also has some of the most immersive aesthetics and mechanics of any game I've ever played. I have learned to approach it with the caution of a recovering drug addict in a pharmacy-- if I click the icon I can expect to lose at least several hours of my time, if not portions of my health, dreams, and/or general human function.

Criticisms: The only reasons I would hesitate to recommend it to my friends in its current state are 1) the effective lack of directed multiplayer, 2) the comparative ease once you start building capital ships, and 3) the lack of polish/balance across some of the playable factions.

1) I found in my playtime that some of what I enjoyed most in the game was the ship design testing process, where at any point you can place your design in the hands of an AI and have it fight best-of-three battles against up to five different AI controlled ships of similar power levels. I would love to have the ability to put my designs up against the designs of my friends and other players, whether one-on-one, faction vs faction, or in larger skirmishes or king of the hill matches.

2) Speaking of the king, once I completed a 8000P juggernaut and spent some time retooling my fleet even the center factions posed little threat (provided I didn't park in a plant faction death cluster or otherwise act a fool). As well, there was no longer any real use for the upgrade currency one you've maxed out the P limit and purchased all the weapon tiles. I haven't tried to achieve complete dominion of the entire game map yet, but the endgame isn't presently as enjoyable as the 20-30 hours I spent reaching it with the first faction (which is a pretty happy problem, granted).

3) As for the factions, the first one has tiles complete with descriptions giving you an idea of each tile's use, as well as some flavor text. The other factions (more recently added to the playable roster) are a bit of a mixed bag, and often require playtesting in order to determine what certain tiles do, or why two similar appearing tiles may have very different power costs. I'm sure this will improve as the game nears release.


Conclusion: This is an excellent indie space sim that melds the fun parts of designing ships with elements of RTS and simple asteroids-style gameplay. It is worth the $30 as is, and I'm excited to see the rest of what the developers pack in before it hits release.

review: Reassembly is a amasing game for creative people that like to mess around with shapes to make some thing sorta like legos but still this game I recamend to people that are very creative, and at times it may be hard to make some ships from factions but after time of thinking who knows what you could make.

author: {'steamid': '76561198143512005', 'num_games_owned': 461, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 14833, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1116, 'last_played': 1642826382}
review:
I have over a hundred hours put into this game, my steam game time is off.


This beautiful diamond amongst rock, is literally the perfect game for those who possess creativity, and love to simply immerse themselves into a game that rewards for said effort contributed unto it.

I have played Hundreds upon Hundreds of rpg's, sandbox's, adventure and action gerne etc.  
This Masterpiece took the elements from many of the games I held dear, and assimilated them all into a free spirited sandbox rpg with not just replayability, but literally the best customization and diversity i've ever seen in an rpg/sandbox.

This game is simple. In said simplicity, there is an elaborate but gradual growth of complexity. The complex part of this game is the factor that you, as a player, control. This factor is your ship! Along with the other ships in your fleet. The more complex and functional you make your ship, the more beautiful it/they may become without you even realizing it.

Having made over a hundred ships, I can vouch for the ship creation system, as it is somewhat pleasing to invest ten minutes to have an exquisite and awe'ing ship emerge :)


Please! If you are contemplating whether or not to invest in this game, let the reviews and hours do the talking! 

It's worth the money.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991986151', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 6349, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4323, 'last_played': 1476564329}
review:
Reassembly is an amazing game.  Similar to how Minecraft combined a 3D action sort of a game with gameplay that revolves around creativity using blocks and crafting, Reassembly does something similar in a sense. The combination of certain creative and radical mechanics with an existing game format makes for something much greater and more enjoyable in Reassembly.  The mechanics of the game when you are flying your spaceship remind me of asteroids, but the game is a lot deeper than that.  Reassembly is a top-down space shooter combined with a very open design mode where players create spaceships out of connectable pieces.  It also features reproducing spaceships :)

In the video posted here on Steam, the creator of the game mentions something about creating things of function and beauty.  In reassembly, both function and beauty are valuable end-goals for player creations.  No one likes an ugly ship.  However, since ships reproduce, it is important that the ships are viable.  If you want a ship to turn well and quickly, you have think out where to place the engines so that they rotate the ship.  If you want to protect the core, you may have to surround it with armor.  Design in the game becomes a very interesting process as the original concepts behind a design merge with the necessary requirements for survivability to generate successful ships, or perhaps I should say, successful offspring.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999841420', 'num_games_owned': 145, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 12935, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1261, 'last_played': 1614196479}
review:
This game may not look like much. Heck, there aren't even any textures, but i must say, Reassembly has quickly become one of my favorite steam games of all time.

The main focus of the game is collecting resources from space plants (which seem to grow on anything that isn't constantly flying at full speed) and ships that belong to enemy factions. These resources can then be sold to friendly stations, who will not only give you credits, but also use the collected resources to build friendly ships, who in turn also collect resources to continue the cycle. Other than the initial ships in the world when you start the game, every ship, turret, and station must be spawned in from a factory (which is attached to another ship, turret, or station) when said factory has enough resources to build. All ships, plants, and debris are persistantly exsistant in the world, even when you leave the area. I cannot express in words how tantalizing the very idea of such a vast yet simple cycle is. Fortunantly, I CAN say (and with absolute certainty) that you MUST buy this game!

PS: The dev team is actually active, so don't be scared of the "early access" label.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087424981', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 22445, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20679, 'last_played': 1579407617}
review:
四角形や三角形などの図形からできたパーツで自分だけの船を組み立て、宇宙を旅していくゲーム。

　早期アクセスということで味方として選べる勢力や使えるパーツは限定的。しかしシンプルながらそれだけに直感的で簡単な組み立てシステムは現時点でもなかなかの魅力を持っている。資金(C)が集まればこれを使って宇宙船の最大サイズ(P)をより大きくしたり、新しいパーツをアンロックできる。工廠設備を導入し、船内に備蓄した資源から味方宇宙船を自給することも可能。

　宇宙には小惑星やそこに生える資源を産む植物、友好／敵対勢力、他のエリアに通じるワームホールや機能の停止したステーションが点在。ステーションは短時間だけ接近することで再起動させ、リスポーン地点候補にできる。ワームホールには新しいエリアへ移動するだけでなく、自艦隊のコピーをどこかの別なプレイヤーに敵勢力として送りつけるという使い道も。
　
　現時点ではストーリーと呼べるようなものはなく、上に書いたものがこのゲームでできることのほぼすべてである。価格はsteam内では少々高額な部類だが、値段に応えられるだけの可能性は十分あると思う。

author: {'steamid': '76561197970327808', 'num_games_owned': 1999, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 2666, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1512, 'last_played': 1653932174}
review:
This is still early access so there is no big story or anything, but still this is a REALLY great game already!
Building your spaceships is incredibly fun, plus updates are quite frequent.
Already you can play as different factions with different blocks (weapons, shields, etc) and the dev promised even more blocks to build ships with. There are wormholes through which you can enter newly created "universes" where there are ships from other players - flying through wormholes will also upload the ships you have built.
I can really recommend this!

author: {'steamid': '76561198009310694', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 718, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 418, 'last_played': 1486597301}
review:
Essentially, if we all think back to the games we played long ago most of us will remember a game where the player controlled a small and weak little fish. Your aim in this game was to swim around in the ocean and eat any of the fish small enough to fit in your mouth and then hall ass away from fishes that were large enough to eat you in one go.

That is a game i feel thay Reassembly can quite easily be compared to. You start off with a small array of 'stock' ships, provided by the dev team to get you started. These are your small fish. As the game provides you with tutorial messages and objectives you will fail at killing a couple of ships as you get used to the aiming and flying mechanics and you will find that if the ship is smaller than yours... It blows up. The moment you see a ship that consists of a number of blocks higher than yours. Run. Or more likely get blown up and respawn. 

But as you kill the little ships and gather your resource, convert it into C and then purchase upgrades or convert it into P. Your ship begins to grow. You test out designs but eventually you realise as long as you make it big and fast and cover it in as many guns you can hide beneath shields... You're doing the a good job. Your ship begins to get larger... You can kill larger ships... Your ship gets larger still. You begin ignoring the smaller craft you once relied on for resources as they are just a minor neusance to you. You feel like a God amongst the stars. Then a Scythe ship one shots you and you start farming those little guys again just to boost your ego back up. 

Great game, very long review. Essentailly Hungry Fish with lasers and 'spolsions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030969096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 4803, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1613, 'last_played': 1549342736}
review: Logged 13 hours in the first 24 of owning it. Kind of like Asteroids meets Gratuitous Space Battles meets heroin. If you like games where you get to customize your ship and love to optimize your design and adapt them to new challenges, this game is for you. Purchased at the $30 price point and never questioned it. First I couldn't believe the 100% positive review ratio, and then I played it. This might be considered Early Access but it's more polished than many fully released studio games. There were no crashes, no glitches, no bugs. Once they get more content this game will enter my top 10 of all time.

review: ビームとかレールガンとかいろいろな武器をつけて戦えます。操作する宇宙船みたいなやつは自分で作れます。作った船で敵を倒しつつ、拠点的なとこを占領して陣地を増やしていける感じだと思う。英語読めなくてもできる読むほど英語使わないアップデートもきてるし今のとこ大丈夫そう公式のムービー見て買うか決めて

author: {'steamid': '76561198038440613', 'num_games_owned': 436, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 6156, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 441, 'last_played': 1678525196}
review:
Reassembly is a game where you start out with a little ship and use various blocks and weapons to upgrade it. Eventually add a factory to it so you manufacture ships, maybe even give them factories so they can make more... 
Put simply, there's a million different things to do. There's a reason this game doesn't have a single bad review - There's next to no complaints. The only thing I could comment on is what I think could be added, but it's all minor stuff like multiplayer.
The style is amazing. Using just vectors and particle physics the game is beautiful and doesn't need textures. It's appealing to the eye and good on those older computers.
The gameplay mirrors this. It's imple WASD to move, mouse to look, and mouse buttons to shoot. However weapon variants are high. Some are turret types that follow your mouse, some are fixed. You've got everything from plasma weaponry (Moderate range and moderate damage) to the feared Antimatter cannon (Moderate range EXTREMELY high damage.)
If you've ever wanted a game that actually brings something new to the "creative sandbox" genre, this game is for you. The price is a little steep but in my opinion this is one of the few Early Access games that deserves the $30. You won't regret it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061383202', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 8284, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7369, 'last_played': 1577044831}
review:
This game is pretty badass, except for all the damage and the amount of cluster fucks the enemies put on you every second, it is pretty good. But really, i would not mind if the game creators decided, for some exttremely smart reason, to put in a difficulty guage so that, well you know, players dont get fucked up every other second

Edit: Wow, in 2014 I sucked apparently. My opinion now is the complete opposite. I am always able to make ships that cannot be defeated. I have made ships so powerful, that I have taken on 23 ship agents at max level, and destroyed all their ships with only one of mine. My ships are so armed, that I don't worry about cramped areas cause I shoot a path through them, completely destroying all debris in the way. 
This game allows you to run tests on the ships you create. The tests involve putting your ship up against a number of different opponents, individually that is. But some opponents have multiple ships, so it is your one ships against multiples at a time. 
There are player made ships throughout the game, as the agents and as other factions. The tests also include player made ships, so there is a lot of diversity. As well as a chance to see what design other people use. 

I'm just going to put this out there, I have created quite a few ships that have never been defeated, and if you ever have to face them, I'm sorry.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991561204', 'num_games_owned': 605, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 988, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 773, 'last_played': 1576272368}
review: Très bon jeu, dévelopeur actif et à l'écoute sur le forum steam , je m'éclate dessus rien a en redire, ce jeu mélange gestion, strategie, action, exploration. Je ne fait que le conseiller à tout le monde ! Il vallait pas son prix avant le 30 Décembre mais maintenant il commence a le valoir ! Un dévelopeur seul qui nous fait un bon jeu c'est rare mais plaisant !

author: {'steamid': '76561198074943301', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 120639, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 108664, 'last_played': 1696676057}
review:
This game has got to be the most addicting game ive played in a few years, even thought not fully finished. I have to say for anyone who loves building space ships this as its going is a must buy. To give you an understanding of the game, you start as a small prebuild ship which over time with enough resources, you can make your own or even just start making your own right away. 

At the start i spent 2 hours building ships and watching the testing battles, rather than actually playing the core game which isn't even done yet. In short this game is great even in Early Access, and unless you play it for your self you will have a hard time seeing if you like this game. But i will say even as fun and addicting as this game is, there are some things not finished and even small down sides. For instance, the gameplay its self is very simple on its own, but is completly over shadowed by the rest of the game which is great.

Honestly i hope people buy this game to try it out as it may not appeal to everyone, but it is in no right a bad game, and i hope for the best that this game will be fantastic and live up to the developers and the communities expectations.

NOTE WAS EARLY ACCESS REVIEW

author: {'steamid': '76561197993617089', 'num_games_owned': 718, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1222, 'last_played': 1419047192}
review:
Short Version:

Crack. Heroin. Nicotine. Alchohol. Reassembly. What do these things have in common? They're all highly addictive. With that being said, Reassembly deffinately has it's faults, but if their's something that interests you about this game, then it's probly worth checking out.

Long Version:

    Reassembly is a 2d, top down, vector graphic space shooter that lets you build your own fleet to conquer the galaxy with. You start out the game with a few premade ships to select from, a faction that looks just like you, and a galaxy full of things that want to kill you. Your objectives are to capture space stations, gather raw resources, turn them into your faction for credits, use those credits to research new parts and upgrade the power of your ship. The further into the galaxy you go, the harder it gets. Whilst exterminating all life that isn't allied to you from the galaxy, you use the very easy to use ship builder to customize or build from scratch both your ship, and your allied ships. (They either automatically spawn based on designs from your inventory, or are spawned by you from a factory ship.) When designing a ship, you can also elect to 'test' your ship in a series of 1v1 ai controlled deathmatches, exactly like the anisoptera contests.

Then there's the asynchronus multiplayer, this game's greatest feature, and biggest pitfall. Essentially, ships that other players have designed will be found strewn throughout the galaxy, in their own factions. Typically, these factions are far stronger than any of the vanilla factions you will encounter, however, that's not true of all of them. For example, one user created a troll ship in the sandbox mode, which allows ship designs that aren't legal in the normal game mode. Only now, here's that ship in _my_ normal game mode. I have a problem with that. Further compounding this problem, are the contest ships. Those ships are purpose built to fall into a specific category of ship, and dominate anything with the same power level or below. Sounds about right, doesn't it? I mean, isn't that the whole point of the contest, and ship design in general? The problem is, you're playing a game that isn't a 1v1 deathmatch. You need storage tanks for your raw resources, factories to spawn your death fleet, and just in general use components that take up space that could be used for more killing devices, or maneuverability. For example, one ship I came across was designed to ram into you, shove a ton of armor between you and his control module, while having 6 plasma cannons on these fragile little arms. The idea being, there's no way for you to chew through his armor before those untouched cannons melt your entire ship. This works great in those ai controlled deathmatches, however it's completely useless in the main game. I'd like to see all sandbox ships blocked from the main game, as well as a user set flag in the designer for "competition mode" or some such, where any ships that have that flag aren't used for the main game.

    I've come across few other issues, like occasionally getting stuck in other objects when changing your ship (solved with a relog) and minor bugs.

    An early access game, and my complaints are fairly minor in nature? Why are you still reading? Go forth and buy immediately! ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561197990417679', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 2963, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1106, 'last_played': 1704945530}
review: This is one must have game. It features amazingly beautify and entrancing gameplay, An always evolving combat and space system, you can literally pass the same area 3 minutes later and have it be completly diffirent. The upgrade system is alot more compex than first glance may imply (fitting just the right pieces to your ship to have the job done, yet having a cap that alters quicly by playing pressures you to grow, but grow to fast and you find yourself in trouble, faceing equally hard enemies.) bored of one world? enter a wormhole and start fresh with your current ships!. I really cannot say enough about this game, I feel lucky to have the chance to play it!

author: {'steamid': '76561198060940728', 'num_games_owned': 728, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 2532, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 644, 'last_played': 1476739516}
review:
I feel beta has been out long enough to write this. I was part of alpha since the summer, and ever since my first glance at the game I was in love. Polygons with partical effects moving polygon clumps that fire polygons with effects at other polygons? What not to love! Although the graphical style is symplistic, it keeps amazing me how complex a ship that's essentially shifting shades of  two colours can look. Gameplay? Great. Although at times I dearly wish there was a way to choose your spawn point so you don't get almost trapped at a station over and over again because enemies keep attacking you as you spawn, it's for the most part rediculously fun trying to continually improve your ship to take down enemies while at the same time making a fleet that's not too shabby for fighting.

What do I Give this? Solid 8/10. It could do better in some respects, so it's not worthy of a nine, and in my opinion no game is ever worth a ten since there are faults in every game, but for the most part I'm in love. I highly recommend this game and I also believe that the thirty dollars will be worth it to help with the development and likely get your ideas implemented, as well as getting to see the game evolve into it's final state like I and many others have been doing for a long time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006535739', 'num_games_owned': 835, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 712, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1638142119}
review:
I have a normal format for my reviews; I will eschew it for Reassembly. Normally I speak of a game's good, bad and ugly qualities, in hopes of bringing excitement for the games perks, and light to its flaws.

I can give this game no higher praise but to say this: I can find no faults in it. The game is brilliantly executed, if perhaps still limited, but then I haven't beaten the game yet. The exploration draws you in in a way that I was utterly surprised by. Since the first day of exploring this title, I have been eager to resume it, to stretch my ship building talents, to bring vengeance to the evil red bastards who always seem to be one step ahead.

The music is nothing short of masterful. Most of the time I tire of the music and mute it in favor of my normal playlists, but the soundtrack is so beautifully atmospheric that there is no need. 

Now let's speak of the elephant in the room, a two headed monstrosity. The first head is the game's graphics. From it's trailer, you have accurately seen the game's aesthetics, and they are indeed simple. Then, you have the $40 price tag, a cost very near a AAA title. I showed this game to a roommate who immediately got sucked in, but when he saw the price, said, "Well, maybe I'll get it if it goes on sale."

Take a look at this game's reviews thus far. It scarcely has more than 30, but EVERY SINGLE ONE of them is positive. I have never seen a 100% approval rating on steam. I take from this two things: For those with the means, you WILL enjoy this title. I guarantee it. Two: It is beyond what most people would reasonably expect to pay.

For a delivery system that has no manufacturing, little overhead, and still in early access, $40 seems steep. It is my opinion that if that price were to get cut in half, its sales would SKYROCKET, by much more than double.

That being said, with EVERYTHING that I said, this game is WORTH the forty dollars.

author: {'steamid': '76561198066508514', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 90, 'playtime_forever': 894, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 742, 'last_played': 1421322316}
review:
ATTENTION:

The price will lower to $10 - $15 on FEBRUARY.

My advice is to wait for the price drop.

but if price isn't an issue for you its definitely worth picking up NOW.

Price aside the game is pretty awesome and its totally what you'd expect or have hopes for. The amount of blocks and the gorgeous art style doesn't disappoint. 

The factions are very very unique from each other and each faction has different kinds of blocks/weapons/ship parts.This game is what Ive been hoping for! Its not overly complicated and and has about 6 or 7 factions at its current build.

It has a random/procedural generated galaxy and has an endless amount of galaxies via wormholes! ( wormholes are the means of travel into other new galaxies ) 

You can upload your fleet/ships and other players would see your ships invading their galaxy! Awesome right?!

For example: Id see a cool ship and if i hover my cursor over it I would be able to see the name of the player who made it and the name of of his ship!

Overall this game is very addicting and would even be more so when more parts are added in the future!

Id score this game a solid:

8.5-9/10 at its current build and could easily be a 10/10 with the more upcoming updates!

I hope this helped! Hurry up and invade my galaxy! I would love to destroy those puny ships of yours!

WAHAHAAHAH! XD

author: {'steamid': '76561198002440676', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 695, 'last_played': 1681468592}
review:
Für alle Fans von SPAZ (Space Pirates and Zombies) ein absoluter muss. Denn man kann seine Flotten bauen wie man lustig ist und ist nicht an irgendwelche vorgefertigten Schiffshüllen gebunden, die dann nur mit Equipment bestückt werden. 

Man entwirft alles selber und hat dafür Punkte zur Verfügung, ähnlich wie bei Spore. Für Credits kann man die Punktezahl erhöhen und neue Teile freischalten. Insgesamt gibt es 3 verschiedene Ressourcen, die da wären: R (man kann es überall sammeln) C (bekommt man für aktivierte Stationen und abgeliefertes R) P (sind die Punkte die man zum Bauen für die Schiffe braucht, welche man für C eintauscht)

Die Stationen denen man die R Ressource bringt, werden ihre eigene Flotte aufbauen und ihre eigenständige Konflikte gegen den Feind führen, sofern welche in der Nähe sind. Mit der [Tab] Taste kann man für C auch Schiffe anheuern die einem dann folgen, dazu muss man sie einfach anklicken und dann wieder [TAB] zum abbrechen drücken. Besser ist aber selber eine Fabrik am Schiff einzubauen und eigene Schiffe zu erzeugen. Das kostet dann nur R.

Nicht jede Verbündete Station benötigt R, also fliegt einfach zu einer anderen, wenn sie nicht wollen, haben sie wohl genug. Am besten fliegt man zu Stationen nahe der Grenze zum Feind.

Leider ist das Spiel komplett auf Englisch, aber es erklärt sich fast von selbst. Wenn man beim Bauen eines Schiffs Schwierigkeiten hat, kann man sich die nötigen Tasten mit deren Erklärung einblenden lassen.

Alle Schiffe die man erstellt hat, werden von der Verbündeten KI nachgebaut und benutzt, sofern sie die benötigten Mittel hat. 

Alles in allem ein sehr gelungenes Spiel, nur ein wenig teuer. 25€ hätten es auch getan.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119572799', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 25067, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1711220660}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025779293', 'num_games_owned': 101, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2027, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 742, 'last_played': 1638485045}
review:
Reassembly is a simple and well executed concept. It is a beautiful, fun game that facinates. The developer works very hard, is involved with the community, and listens to ideas! I cannot wait to watch this game go from beta to release. The Beta is VERY stable with a few UI design that need some tweaking. But this does not mar the game at all.

It is so easy to get lost in Reassembly. I continually tweak, change, upgrade, rehash, redesign, and customize my ships. Its facinating to watch your own creation evolve as you gain access to more and more powerful weapons. Such a joy.
The world is vast in scope, colorful, busy, living and beautiful. The "grind" in this game is fun because you get to build, test and tweak your ship exactly the waty you want too.

There are three different ways to control the ship which can take some getting use too, but they all work very well. The art choice is stellar, and beautiful. And the ambiant music sets such an amazing tone as you realize you are a very small dot in a expansive universe. Nothing is as exciting as watching your mini probe evolve into a giant mother ship.

Not enough good things can really be said. If you dont want to pay the price now, wait till its cheaper. The game is highly worth it either way! I shall leave it at this, if not i will just continue rambling.

But really...its Legos that actually fire lazers and fly. How can you say no?

author: {'steamid': '76561197961397363', 'num_games_owned': 794, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 2245, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 349, 'last_played': 1585510680}

author: {'steamid': '76561198015539882', 'num_games_owned': 3125, 'num_reviews': 142, 'playtime_forever': 318, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 318, 'last_played': 1417296113}
review:
As of Beta build from Nov 26:
Reassembly is kind of the game that takes one and only one thing and does it very very well. In this case it's crazy custom ship skirmishes.
Target of the game is pretty simple - conquer the whole map. And all you have to accomplish that is you own ship, some raw resources and a couple of supporting space stations.
You have to farm (literally, they grow on space plants) resources, fight enemies, build your fleet and slowly proceed to the center of the map. That's a game in a nutshell. But, I want to stress this once more, the game does this one thing very VERY good.
Add here a nice async multiplayer - all players can share their ship builds online, and those shared ships will appear in other players' games. Which is pretty awesome if ask me.
But is it enough? Well, that's for you to decide. If you ask me - it definitely is.
Oh, and don't forget the amazing soundtrack!

More detailed look in the video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VG-RP0yBg8M

author: {'steamid': '76561198059740355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 3022, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1000, 'last_played': 1585426627}
review:
This game is lots of fun, especially if you already enjoy shipbuilders. Constructing your ship is simple, and you can even test it against other AI before you take a spin in it. Gameplay so far is farely simplistic. Build up your faction by collecting resources and designing better ships to take on the other factions. Buy new parts to upgrade your ships. Upgrade your ships. Blow up other ships. Despite the simplicity the game is tons of fun and I highly recommend it.

And don't forget, this is only in beta, so I have good hopes of more content being added on later.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002734128', 'num_games_owned': 3358, 'num_reviews': 928, 'playtime_forever': 283, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 107, 'last_played': 1548298110}
review:
A very interesting concept that is implemented well.  I am not someone who enjoys overly complex "X" (ships, mechs, etc.) builders and I'm pleased to report that designing my own ship in this game was incredibly easy.  Essentially, you'll start off with a small ship, earn credits and raw resources, and then build up both your ship and faction in an attempt to get to the center of the map (the difficulty increases as you go, like in "Spore").

It's a bit pricey for the content it currently offers, though to be fair, the price listed now is actually higher than what it'll be at launch.  This was intended so as to "ensure a higher degree of focus between us and our testers/players."  Those who really enjoy games of this type and don't mind the aspect of Beta testing and playing Early Access games would be best suited to pick this up.  Otherwise, wait for launch and grab it then.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RSlhT-7ieVI

author: {'steamid': '76561198007324693', 'num_games_owned': 724, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 16827, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 4124, 'last_played': 1486744067}
review:
Upon trying this out, I really did not know what to expect. At first, however, I found myself a little lost in this strangely organic world that is somewhere in the far reaches of space.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=swxfEZJtZAk
It doesn't take long for you to realize that you are not alone, and, in fact, you have a whole faction that shares your own desire for expansion in the untamed universe. Unlike many in this loose genre, you fight side by side with your AI friends from beginning to end. 

Make no mistake, this is, at it's core, a block building game, where you build your spaceship, and can build fleets of custom ships to fight with you or just let them loose to go it on thier own. Where they will build more ships of thier own and fight the good fight for the faction gathering resources and growing your empire just like yourself. In many ways, when I play this I feel like just another small, but important, peice of a larger hive doing my part. Although I would like to think that I might contribute a little more than my AI companions, I hope. 

In Reassembly, you will explore, expland, exploit, and exterminate. Yes, this is, in fact, a 4X game, hidden underneath a very well crafted version of a top down space shooter. 

The more I play, the more I want to play, and I find myself losing time. It's worth the money.
